author: ForeverPositive
title: The News is Making Me Depressed and Anxious

postContent.comment: I'm trying to limit my time watching the news, as it is so depressing, but it's so hard to get away from as coworkers, friends, and family members constantly talk about what's happening.I'm particularly getting anxious due to the situation with Iran and possible revenge against the U.S. I live in a populated city and am anxious about attacks. I know I can't let fear stop me from living my life, but it's hard to do when you see a huge increase in security and people telling you to be extremely vigilant.If it's not the news, I get down about not having health insurance and financial stability. I'm also worried about  not having retirement. I have absolutely nothing in retirement and can't save much, as I live paycheck to paycheck at the moment.Sometimes, I feel like a hamster on a wheel.

ForeverPositive said...I'm trying to limit my time watching the news, as it is so depressing, but it's so hard to get away from as coworkers, friends, and family members constantly talk about what's happening.I'm particularly getting anxious due to the situation with Iran and possible revenge against the U.S. I live in a populated city and am anxious about attacks. I know I can't let fear stop me from living my life, but it's hard to do when you see a huge increase in security and people telling you to be extremely vigilant.If it's not the news, I get down about not having health insurance and financial stability. I'm also worried about  not having retirement. I have absolutely nothing in retirement and can't save much, as I live paycheck to paycheck at the moment.Sometimes, I feel like a hamster on a wheel.I was in New York City on 9/11 when we got attacked.  I also was very anxious for awhile after that.  The security over those next few years and now has been increased.  Strange, but it makes me feel more secure.  I just put in my head that when and if it's your time, there is nothing you can do about it.  Live your life, enjoy each day.

If I lived in a major American city, maybe I'd feel a little bit worried about America being attacked.However, I live in rural Maine.  The chances of my area being hit are so low and unlikely that I don't worry about it at all.

Not in usa, but our sensationalism  on death and trauma andThe allowance of this voyeurism has instilled a conformity because theIdiot box has become God. I not watch the death and trauma and report (news) and ifKim kardashin had intense diarreah! The world is no longer safe. Rural means squat when ya drop an atom bomb. Before I break the rules Hiroshima did not discriminate.  HT.

As with all other worries this also is out of our hands.  I find mindful walking and sitting in stillness, if only for 5 min is helpful. Perhaps it my past, I constantly remind myself that I will not let the future or others actions, including IRANS take my contentment or joy [little that I have at times] away. lI watch CNN for an hour, couple times a week, so I am aware of what to pray for, this is my faith. Sure it is hard not to become over anxious and let it over.  But that is what I have skills for.   Put world  right next to my abusive family and cheating husband that I have been separated from for 2.5 years. I hope this helped in some way.  Peace, strength and calm.Trina

I just figure what happens happens.  We have no control.  I will still live my life day to day.  Hopefully I will have my meds.  And food, and heat.  But if not, then we cope the best that we can.  Anxiety or no anxiety.Hugs to all...Karen...

Watching the news or reading news on the net is truly depressing.  Most of all the innocents are involved.   I truly agonize when those who have no ability to stand on their own are abused.  Animals especially.  I hate abuse of any kind.  I live in the States and our government is ridiculous.  From top to bottom its all a big joke.  I would love to have a government which actually cared about the people instead of how they can make themselves rich.  Sorry for the rant.  I watch the news but just to search for a ray of hope amidst the clouds and rain.  I am just searching for a kind word.  A caring person.dmo

Well,  not country is ideal, just as NO family is the Waltons.The TV series was based on the real family, then dramtized, blah, blah, blahWay I see it?Start with Self compassion, get strong in who are, know your morals or lack of.Then you can start putting energy out into your corner of the world.  No one person can change a neighborhood, a town, city, country.However,  do a nice ir compassionate thing each day, that ripple goes farMy grandmother told me once why she didnt make quilts anymore."Because there are no other women to make squares and bring to the bee"So you see, up to 20 women would make squares 5-10 then on a weekend they would sit around the frame and make a quilt in 36 hours, all hand stitched Now if 20 women could get along for that long. There is hope for all of us!!PeaceTrina

I am sorry Trina, I did not mean our country was horrible.  I am frustrated the people who need help here seldom get it.  This is a great country with many people giving their lives in its defense.  You are right in that friendship and love start with us.  We take the time to help others and hopefully these others help still more people. My wife is a quilter and she has taught me to make quilts also.  I put the squares together and then form a chain.  She puts on the binding and backing.  I never thought I would like doing this but was pleasantly surprised.  I think its the little things in life that make us the happiest.  Please feel betterdmo
How awesome about the quilts...Just saying...Michele, that must of been scary.  It would effect a person for a long time to come.  I am glad you are okay.Hugs, Karen...

My country is going down the worst path possible: of course I am depressed and anxious about it. I can do absolutely nothing except watch in numb outrage as all the things that were predicted to happen happen - I have no power to stop any of it. I wish I hadn't lived to see this far in history, because I don't think it's going to get any better from here. I could be wrong, but I'm not seeing any plausible path by which things can improve rapidly enough to stop the impending catastrophe. It's as though we are locked in a death spiral, with the right wing  insisting everything is absolutely fine and everyone else screeching impotently that it isn't. We are not just putting ourselves at risk of extinction, but every other species on this planet too. But sure, a few insects will probably survive. Microorganisms too. Mammals, fish and birds: not so much. I try not to think about it too much, because it could make a person crazy. And not many people want to hear my bleak view of humans.Edit: Sorry for being so depressing :-/Post Edited (NiceCupOfTea) : 1/12/2020 5:35:17 PM (GMT-7)

When I am depressed I just don't care about me, but I still care about my children.  So I try to recycle and re-use, drive less and so on.  The next car I buy is going to be a hybrid.  I really do believe in "Think globally and act locally".  30 years ago I lived two miles further up the road that I do now.  They cut into a large piece of mountain to put the highway in and rocks fall onto the road on a regular basis.  I used to worry every time I drove it (more than twice a day, usually) that a rock was going to fall and kill me and my children would be alone, etc.  It got to be too much so I finally made my peace with the rocks because there was no way I could control whether they fell or not.  Now, when I feel my anxiety ratcheting up about things I can't control, I try to remember making peace with the rocks and it helps me refocus.Kathy

Oceanfisher- I feel exactly how you do about our government. I know that no country is perfect, but I also get frustrate as people do not get the help that they need as you rightly said. Right now, I'm anxious because I don't have health insurance and need to see a doctor. Grrr...one day at a time I guess.NCOT-I like reading your views as I feel it is similar to mine. I  really empathize with you as things also seem unstable on this side of the pond. As a matter of fact, it seems like most countries are a mess right now. The only thing that gives me hope is that there are a lot good people fighting to protect the rights of others.  It makes me happy that there are still people in this world with morals.Bnot-Your absolutely right. If 20 women can get along, there is hope for us all. LOL.I have limited my time watching the news, but still feel a bit anxious. My anxiety came out yesterday when I was in church. There was odd person there and my anxiety heightened a little because of all the shootings or assaults at places of worship. It has gotten so bad that my pastor stated that he and other religious leaders are thinking of hiring security. It is so unbelievable that people now have is a fear of going to a place of worship. I guess all I can really do is live my life and take things as they come.

All we can really do is take things as they come FP.  Unless we hide at home, like I sometimes do.  It is much easier than worrying about the big scary world sometimes.  Things can get better.  Hang onto that thought.  It takes time and process but it could happen.  Hang in there.  It's a shame when you have to have security everywhere, but it is worth it.Hugs, Karen...

author: astroman
title: Happy / SAD lights? I need some winter motivation

postContent.comment: Hello, I realize there's some people really hurting here, I had that with lyme (dep/anz is common with that).  Now its very minimal and more like lite anxiety coupled with low motivation in winter. I take 5htp and a few herbs like passion flower for anxiety, but its almost non-existent after the holidays. The low motivation is stealing my time away. Winter snow and cold and gloomy days make me want to couch a whole lot more, but not in a depressed way, just a lazy way. I never seem to get my to do list done,but -  I don't imagine anyone who lives alone with in an older home and older vehicles never gets every thing completely done (?). Always one repair or maintenance item after another. In the summer Im a very active person, but certainly not the energizer bunny, I go in spurts till I get tired and take a nap after work. I get burned out very easy. Being introverted makes tired around people too (from work), nothing I can fix there. And lyme disease changes the body to some extent sometimes forever. 90% healed is what most end up with. I dont drink or use any rec drugs legal or not. So, thats my intro, I might have posted here a long time ago, dont remember. ****Can these light help with motivation? Or are they only effective for the severely depressed? ***I know lack of light turns on the meitonine sleep hormone. Im in very northern US, less daylight and cloudy when it is day. The late Feb sun (more sun, still cold) ,motivates me. I love spring and hate fall (short days). Will using the light for ten min in the morning bathroom before work help? Not going to set the alarm earlier to sit by a light. Heard it said if you use them at night- it affects sleep, true? (makes sense).thankswaiting for spring

Hi Astroman,The light helped me.  I use to have a light box.  I had it on my kitchen table and would sit by it in the morning.  Now it could just be my imagination but I felt it helped.  I think it wouldn't hurt to try.  I don't know about it effecting sleep when used at night.  But I imagine if you were awake it would be hard to fall asleep. So yes, it does make sense.I live in northern lower Michigan and I know all about the shorter days and lack of sunlight.  I go outside a little with my dog everyday so I am getting some sun like today.  But there are often cloudy days.  So I would try it if I were you.  Insurance might pay for it if you have.  I think it paid for mine and that was in the 90's.  So they are more apt to pay for one now.  I hope you try it and I hope that it helps.And if you haven't been here before, welcome to the depression forum.  But I think I remember your name.Hugs, Karen...

I say yes!Dead of winter, 10min cleaning up the yard from my dog can make me feel better.So to just stand out side would be beneficle, woth a coat of courseI also have take vitamin A in winterPeaceTrina

I have a 'full spectrum' lamp...the bulb looks sort of like a fork made out of fluorescent tubes.  I know it helps my indoor plants grow and helps me!   I used to use it every day in my living room.  Now, I use it if I'm having too many 'down days' in a row.I find that if I keep my home warm (around 70) and open the curtains for as much natural light as will come in here in NJ, then close them at sundown and turn the interior lights on...then 'create' my own 'sundown' by turning first one light, then another, and another about 15 minutes apart...starting with the ones on the east side of the house and ending with one on the west side of the house last...before heading down to bed after turning the heat back to about 62...seems to be a great help, too.  I have a 3 light standing lamp on either side of my living room, so I start with a total of 6 lit, then 5, 4, 3, 2, 1.I have dogs that must go outside and we are not allowed to let them out unattended, which means I'm out there with them, several times a day!  If it's decent out, I throw the ball for them to fetch back.  If it's not 'nice' out...they pretty much do business and then right back inside!  I clean the yard at least once each day, regardless of the weather.  A bit of fresh air and natural light can do wonders, even if it's brief.

I have used a SAD lamp for five years, which I clearly believe improves my depression. My symptoms are worse in the short winter days. I use mine for 45 minutes in the morning while I watch the news.I would recommend getting a good quality lamp. Northern Lights Flamingo has worked well for me - about $200.

I used to get depressed every winter, as I live in cold and snowy Maine.  I started to suspect that I had Seasonal Affective Disorder.  I also started to consider using phototherapy (light therapy).However, ever since going on the psychiatric medication called Clozaril back in 2011, I haven't had depression issues during the winter, I'm happy to say.

Thank for the replies. I should have added I do outdoor winter trail sports /activities if its above 10F.  on the weekends, which fels good once I talk myself into doing it . Since I work full time with a commute, there is no daylight left in my free time during the week. I get AM daylight in the work parking lot for 20 seconds a day LOL.1)Will using the light for ten min in the morning bathroom before work help? - since I need to get going in the AM, I wont be sitting around in front of anything, thats why I ask this.  2)Heard it said if you use them at night- it affects sleep. ..... Not true?I try to be as Rx free as possible, although I realize thats not an option for some people. I was depressed when I had lyme disease which is a very common symptom (Lyme is common in the colder Great Lakes and NE States).  After years of that, I'm now cured. This is different, its more lack of motivation and sleepyness, not depression, and only in winter. thanksPost Edited (astroman) : 1/8/2020 7:04:57 PM (GMT-7)

A bright light that I used for many years fits right on your head using a ball cap, so you can go about your daily activities.  It's great for the short grey days in the Pacific NW.www.feelbrightlight.com
Tim G-  Thats a pretty cool invention, I will look into it more.

Do you have snow where you are Astroman?  I just thought, I use to cross country ski and it gave me a lot of energy and I felt real good.  It is hard for me to do now, but I wish I could.  I was always real warm in the winter when I skied.Hugs, Karen...

getting by- Yes, I XC ski weather permitting.  I snowshoe and winter fatbike too. Thats all fun if its above 10F and not windy (gets cold here), but no light to do that during a workweek; I need a daily dose.But nothing beats more light. Cant wait for a breezy sun filled summer 75F day on a lake.  Or just coming home after work in the summer to sit on the front steps in daylight.Maybe ill be a "snow bird" someday, the south is just to hot to live there in the summer, would be a nice winter escape though. Im a useless slug in hot humidity. Guess Im a "fair weather" critter.
U can get sunnies that help. Our uni did a study. Keep strong. HT

author: NiceCupOfTea
title: Hope you have a slightly less miserable Christmas

postContent.comment: I think "happy" might be going too far for most of us. Not sure what to say now I'm here. I left, because I felt like I was boring everyone, including myself, with my long, dreary, rambling posts. The depression came back and I had nothing to say that anyone wanted to hear, in real life or online. I felt like a ghost, literally: moving unseen through a world where I had no place. My social anxiety and panic attacks increased and even leaving my flat to walk to the supermarket or town centre became another form of torture. I guess you heard about the election in the UK? From my point of view it was the worst result imaginable. We'll get our hard, patriotic Brexit. Our democratic institutions, judiciary, etc. will be hollowed out. The long term project of privatising the NHS will continue apace but in private of course, so the plebs don't cotton on until it's too late to backtrack. Etc. etc. The only silver lining for me is that I don't care anymore. I could not feel less a part of this country if I tried to. I may as well be an alien.My Crohn's is also depressing me at the moment. Thinking of returning to a permanent ileostomy while we still have an NHS, but that comes with its own set of worries and issues. It's not a panacea, otherwise I would book the operation tomorrow. Okay, I took a short break because I couldn't decide whether to post this as it is or try to inject a note of optimism to dilute the relentless bleakness. I'm lazy so relentless bleakness it is. But, ironically enough, I now feel slightly better for the short break, so I do feel more capable of injecting a note of extremely tentative and wary optimism. A few weeks ago, I was all ready to give into the depression in the most final way (I woudn't have done, but only because of my mum). Now, I'm teetering on the edge between wanting to give in and wanting to find a pathway out of the seemingly endless forest of depression. Take care, folks. Look after yourselves as best you can. I am off to my parents' house now, where I'm making homemade eggnog.

Homemade eggnog is something worth enjoying. I am sorry you're feeling down. Sometimes I think the holidays emphasize sadness for people with "alternative lifestyles". By alternative, I mean single people and people without a lot of family/friends. Holidays are for people who blend in with society... people who remain in the town they were born, marry and have children. I always feel the most lonely at the holidays, but at least I am off of work, that is something to celebrate. Two days in a row where I don't have to do meaningless nonsense for a dollar...The political situation over here is also bad. You are actually lucky you've lived a large portion of your life with the social services you have. Imagine you lived here? I know that's not the point, but it's our reality. Hopefully, things change for the better at some point soon. Isn't what you fear basically how we live here? Sometimes I get down about it, and then I realize that I have at least prevented it from happening to someone else by not having children, and I am getting old, perhaps politically things can't get too much worse in my lifetime? One thing I know is that waiting for things to get better usually leads to nothing. You have to go out and work hard to improve your situation. The problem is, no matter how hard we work, we will still just teeter on the edge of failure. That's my life anyway. Whatever happened with your plan to get a pet? Enjoy the day with your family.

Hi Miranda,You are far from being boring.  And this forum is for when you feel down, we will be here for you.  I was missing you so I am glad you posted.  I was going to do a shout out but I did before and didn't know if it would be repetitious..  Though you would probably have seen it and hopefully responded.My mind is full.  I went to town today (Christmas Eve).  I went shopping with some other people and I am toast.  I get tired easy.  So I will write more to you later.  Just happy to see you post.  Hope you get to feeling better Miranda.  I agree with NSSG.  Our political situation is bad...  Though we aren't suppose to discuss it.  There are two sides and it leads to arguments.  But we can always email.Have a good night...Hugs, Karen...

Hi nssg and Karen. The good news? I actually had a really nice Christmas Eve, the best I've had in years I think. The dinner was simple but lovely (crusty bread, smoked salmon, prawns, ham, plus a marie rose sauce I made for the prawns - marie rose sauce can be a tad bland, so I gave it a kick up the arse with brandy and tabasco sauce). Then I caught up on the BBC's 3-part adaption of A Christmas Carol and we watched the last part together, followed by a half hour ghost story afterwards. I had two massive glasses of eggnog, along with several Lindt chocolates. The bad news? My other brother, who I don't like and don't get along with, is coming tomorrow with his family. It'll be infinitely more boring, hearing their boring conversation and being left out, as I always was when I was a child. My brother is the sort of dullard bore who has zero imagination and empathy and I would be quite happy if I never saw him again. Already feeling stressed out at the thought of spending 3-4 hours sitting around that dull table, eating the dull turkey, and listening to the dull conversation - nobody even plays any board or card games! (My mum doesn't like them). Perhaps I will leave the table before my nephews do, so I at least get first dibs at the TV in my mum's bedroom. Otherwise they'll take over it for the whole evening. There you go. That's my Christmas Day rant 24 hours early.... >.> @nssg - I don't want to get too political, but we are leaving the EU in order to become like America. You say I'm lucky and, yes, I have been so far. But I'm not getting any younger or healthier and, unlike you, an operation never cured my IBD. Last night I got up about 6x to go to the toilet. That's crazy and I can't carry on like that. This is easily as bad as it was pre-surgery; the only difference is I don't get fevers anymore or only rarely. I live in fear of the future. We are, at least regards welfare, already like you: austerity has been brutal to millions and we now have more foodbanks in the UK than McDonald's and Burger Kings combined. (Before the Tories, I think we had about two.) I am well aware of my relative good luck so far, but I do not expect it to hold out for another 40-50 years.  And as long as my parents are still alive, I will always have a home to go back to, but my mum is 80 and my dad is 84: they are hardly spring chickens. I don't see things improving in the UK in my lifetime for reasons I won't bore you with. Nobody would be happier than me to be wrong, but the path we have chosen to go down is not one that can easily be rescinded.  Once the NHS has gone that's it for example. No government will bring it back again, it was a creation of its time (post-war). I know I ought to work, but I'm 44, haven't worked for 20 years, have serious mental health problems and autism, along with various physical issues. It's not like there's any support from anywhere. My parents don't have a clue how to help me and I can't blame them, because I don't have a clue how to help myself. I could try to gain a qualification if it's not too expensive, but I have no idea what employers want, what skills are useful, what are a waste of time. I was thinking of IT, but IT is an incredibly broad subject. And would anyone really hire a nearly 50 year old with no work experience? I don't know. Anyway, I'm getting all depressing and dour again, so I'll shut up :-/Just to say, I'm sorry you have to work, because it's obvious you don't enjoy it one little bit. And I can't say I blame you. But it isn't a bed of roses in my position either. It's a pity neither of us can find more pleasure in life. @Karen - Yo :p Thank you! It is nice to see you again. How are you doing?Don't worry about not posting a lot. I get tired really easily too. I think at the moment I'm a bit buzzed from eggnog... >.> Also, if I have any energy at all, it's usually ridiculously late at night, at about the time I should be going to bed... I'll try to refrain from talking about politics after this post. Think I've said everything there is to say about the current situation and there's not much to add.On a happier note, I'm going to look for a dog after Christmas. Sadly, there will probably be more abandoned puppies/dogs than usual due to the time of the year, so I will look for a rescue dog. And this time: no excuses. If I really can't manage to walk it locally where I am (due to noise, traffic, people), then I can always put it in a car and go somewhere quieter.

Merry Christmas Miranda...  Thanks for posting back.  I am up early.  I always wake up early on Christmas Mornings.  Watching for Santa I guess.  Ha...I hope you (and everybody) have a nice day!!!I will be cooking soon.Hugs, Karen...

Can you take something to help with the nighttime trips? I wouldn't mind taking something myself. Getting up in the night is the worst, but I just get up and go back to bed. I know Andrina was having a lot of night trips and she's on an antibiotic and doing much better. I know you've likely exhausted a lot of the options, as you've been dealing with this for a while, but maybe there is something that would help. Keith has mentioned tincture of opium. Have you have the opportunity to try that? As for your mom's house today, that sounds frustrating. At the same time, I usually let the kids do what they want. How many kids is it? You're just one person. It's worth getting the kids off everyone's backs perhaps? Sad that that is how I see it, . Is your brother married? Is his wife also a boring drag? I would imagine so. Maybe you can take off early and go see friends? Or enjoy some time with the kids... Are they terribly bratty? Maybe the day will be better than you think. It sounds like yesterday ended up being a great day, why not today too?That's a great idea about adopting. Cats are also nice companions, and much easier to care for overall. The only problem with a cat is that they can be quite destructive and they don't "get you out of the house". Dogs require a lot of walks and you can take them to the dog park. it's more social. Are you definitely getting a dog? A small one? I drive my dogs to go walking. it's very chaotic where I live. A lot people in the city area also don't curb and you will end up with poop on your shoe, or on the dog's feet, which is unhealthy for everyone involved. I don't mind driving to the park where it's clean to walk. As for work, I don't know about whether you're going to get hired at your first corporate job, or start a career, at nearing 50  (though it's not impossible), but there are tons of regular jobs that hire all sorts of people. If you get a skill that's in demand, even if it's a relatively simple certification, I am sure you would get hired. I see people doing all sorts of assistant jobs with relatively no experience or specified education. You're smart too, you would be easy to train. I guess being socially uncomfortable would be the bigger issue - I deal with that majorly too.Have a great Christmas!!

I want to wish you two and everybody a Merry Christmas.Miranda, have you ever thought about taking a class?  Something to stimulate the brain?  Maybe even photography as you are talented at that, or even an art class?  Painting I think you would be good at.  It would pass some time and would give you something to enjoy...  Just a thought.NSSG, I hope you are having a good Christmas.  How are your dogs?  As I am trying to recall you had small greyhounds?  Maybe Italian or wippets?  I can't spell it.  But I remember you would take them out for a hike.  Anyway, I hope you have a good day.Hugs,,, Karen...

MirandaIt is nice to see you postPolitics is something we all [including me]Need to see. We can vote for change, but outside of that, it is out of our control.  Anything out of my control I am trying very hard to giving my contentment away to.It is scary.  But i cut my CNN VIEWING down to 1hour a dayI am still alive after the major holidays. This is a good thing.Ruined a painting today, need to start over.Is ok, I have a better idea and will use a bigger canvas.Peace AllTrina
Hi Turtle!

BnotAfraid said...MirandaIt is nice to see you postPolitics is something we all [including me]Need to see. We can vote for change, but outside of that, it is out of our control.  Anything out of my control I am trying very hard to giving my contentment away to.It is scary.  But i cut my CNN VIEWING down to 1hour a dayI am with you on the not worrying about things I can't control stuff. I would go nuts if I let everything out of my control get me worked up.Karen, yes italians  They are the sweetest little babies on the planet! How is your baby girl?Hope you're all having a happy and positive holiday season.

NSSG,I lost the one I use to have in May 2018.  But I have since gotten another girl.  She is doing okay.  I took her in on the 11th and got her spayed.  She had been chewing herself and got a bad skin infection and they put her on strong antibiotics for a month.  But the antibiotics are causing severe diarrhea.  So I am calling the vet today.  I might take her in for the antibiotic shot.  She has been taking them for two weeks and the shot lasts two weeks so that will be the month worth.  I am just hoping the shot doesn't give her bad diarrhea.  I feel sorry for her.  She chases her tail and bites it.  I have blood all over the house because she spins and spins.  I am hoping she grows out of this or else there is going to be no more tail.  She just wont leave it alone.  I think she gets bored.  Was thinking about getting her a companion but it is so expensive for just one around here with an expensive vet.  And she has tummy issues so I had to switch dog foods.  Poor girl.  This dog food is for sensitive skin and stomach.  We'll see after the antibiotics are done.  Giving her Pedialyte too to keep her from getting dehydrated.  I hope your pups are doing well.  And you too.  I hope you have a safe and happy new year.Hugs, Karen...

That is frustrating. I would take her to a vet dermatologist. It sounds like maybe she has dermatitis or allergies? My dog has dermatitis and he's on atopica for it. He still licks a bit, but the really bad itchy skin and bumps are gone. There are weaker drugs you could try first of course! My dogs also suffer with frequent stomach issues. They eat "vet diet" food, but it's very expensive, and it doesn't help all the time. They will have flareups of whatever it is. I call it IBD but the vet doesn't seem all that interested in actually diagnosing and treating it, they just want to do tests and never give long-term treatment or diagnosis. I try to keep flagyl on hand since their issue responds to that, but often it's difficult to get vets to prescribe it even though it's the only thing that keeps them from constant D. Go here and see if there's a dermatologist near you https://www.acvd.org/It's a tough cycle, skin issue, drugs, D. At least if you can manage the skin issue without antibiotics, maybe you can get the D to let up. Have you tried pumpkin? or tylosin can help... Did you do stool tests? When you think about it, what is the antibiotic treating?  A potential infection? From what? There must be a condition that you can treat before you require the antibiotic. I hope so.

NSSG,The closest to me is 200 miles.  But you gave me something to think about.  Her skin condition.  The new dog food I got is for sensitive skin and stomach.  So I think that helps some.  I will look into a prescription food though.  I haven't tried pumpkin but I started cooking rice.  The vet office said to get some Imodium AD.  So I guess I will try that.  Maybe our pets just have a total sensitive system.  Everything.  I know mine also has diarrhea when she gets stressed.  But I think it is from the antibiotics.  I just want her to have some relief.  Thanks for writing back.  It helps when somebody understands what you are going though.  Hugs, Karen...
Awesome sharing compassion. Keep 💪 everyone. The 🐢 is moving into the idea of a fur companion again. HT

Hi folks. This will be a fairly quick update, as it's late and I didn't get any sleep last night. I thought I had posted about Christmas Day already, but I hadn't. Long story short: It went okay >_>. I did go a bit mental with the Lyrica (think that's its brand name) and codeine (I took 2 pills of each), which perhaps helped explain why. The pills also helped a lot with my Crohn's, which was an unexpected relief. Unfortunately I'm back to normal now, as there is no way my GP will prescribe me that much codeine or Lyrica, or indeed either at all. Anyway, the day went well. Dinner was nice and even my family didn't irritate 7 bells of hell out of me. Boxing Day was quiet, just watched a couple of films with my mum and brother. Why are ghost stories so bad nowadays? We watched a ghost story which trotted out every single cliche of the genre at least 30 times each, because it's bound to be even scarier on the 30th go, m i rite? On the 27th I went with my mum and my brother to my aunt's house. It started off loud and ascended to ear-splitting, as more people arrived. There was music, but it was not the music: no music could drown out this lot. They are the loudest people known to man. There is no conversation that they can't bellow out at top volume. Everyone in that house is also a fanatical Brexiter and I think I heard every Brexit cliche that night too. Fortunately I'd had enough alcohol by then to mellow me a bit. It's a weird situation because my aunt has been quite kind to me, but I do feel like I'm living on a different planet to my family (excluding my mum and brother) - I just have nothing in common with any of them. On the 28th the Christmas excesses finally caught up with me and I had a day of feeling wretched. I even had a fever, probably Crohn's-related. Used to get them all the time, but since surgery that's the one symptom I rarely have anymore. It's just everything else which is awful.Oh yeah, also saw my GP for the first time in a year! (Don't ask me why, otherwise I will go into a long and bitter spiel about the not-fit-for-purpose appointments system and it's too late for that.) She is really good though, I have to say. I got my blood test results back and found out I have anaemia and elevated TSH. Need an iron infusion and my levothyroxine has been increased to 125mcg. I also asked about a little-known antidepressant called Valdoxan - I don't think it is available in the US, but it did sound quite promising when I googled it. I think my GP would have prescribed it to me if she could, but apparently GPs are not allowed to prescribe it, so I'll have to get in touch with the mental health team at my local mental health centre. I hope I do not see the same useless, patronising doctor that I saw last time, as I did not like her. Phew. That's about it. Didn't do much yesterday apart from wreck my foot. Oh yes. Forgot about that one  I banged my foot into a table leg by accident. It was excruciatingly painful for a minute or two, then I laid down on the sofa and forgot about it. Didn't notice it again until I had to dash to the toilet... It didn't look that bad, but it was *really* painful to walk on. I worried I might have a fracture instead of a sprain. But today, it was easier to walk around the flat. Yay! Then I put on my shoes to walk to the supermarket, which is literally a 5 minute walk if that. I had to turn back halfway, it was that painful - even undoing the laces didn't do anything. Nooo! I'm meant to be going out with my mum and brother tomorrow. Even driving will be difficult, judging by this. But by hook or crook I'm going, even if I have to dose up with painkillers and wear sandals and look like a weirdo in January. Really don't want to spend another day doing nothing in my flat. Anyway, that's my update. Super exciting isn't it? <_<. I want to go to bed now, which doesn't leave me any time to answer your questions and this post is probably already long enough, really. But I would like to say something before I go. @Karen - Your dog sounds stressed. She is both young and a German Shepherd and German Shepherds are a high energy breed. I am not saying it would solve every problem she has, but I do think exercise would almost certainly help. I know it is hard for you to get out, but would you consider hiring a dog walker to walk her? Is there anywhere she can run around, like a field or a park? Does she have toys to play with at home, bones to chew? Sorry for all the questions; I'm just trying to help you help her feel better. Okay, I'd better go now. I'll let you know how tomorrow and my foot went :p Goodnight, everyone.

Hi NCOT,I'm glad to hear that your Christmas went okay. Christmas seems to be the one holiday which causes some people to become very depressed. If I'm completely honest, I don't care for Christmas, as it has become very commercialized,but I do enjoy spending time with my parents, who I only see once a year as they live in a different state.Sorry to hear about the anemia. I suffered from it on-and-off throughout the years. My doctor told me to take an iron tablet with orange juice for better absorption. I am also taking blackstrap molasses which supposedly increase your iron level. I hope your foot heals and you feel better soon.It's unfortunate that politics seem to be the main focus of discussion during family gatherings, especially when your views differ from your relatives or friends. I would love to have at least one day go by without anyone mentioning Trump as I am tired of hearing about him. However, I didn't mind when my cousin discussed Brexit as it gave me some insight as to how scared some people feel. My cousin and her family live Birmingham, but recently came to the states for a visit. She is scared and very  worried about what is happening. She is  particularly nervous about the effects Brexit may have on getting medical supplies; she needs to take certain medications and is afraid that she may not be able to receive it.  Sigh...everything seems to be spiraling into chaos. Hopefully, next year will be good.Anyway, I hope you have a good time with your mum and brother. Happy New Year!Post Edited (ForeverPositive) : 12/30/2019 8:15:09 PM (GMT-7)

Happy New Year to all!!!  Miranda,  Thanks for replying.  Luna does need exercise.  I know she is bored out of her mind.  She got a new toy for Christmas and plays with it a lot.  She has some kind of allergies.  I am going to call the vet today.  I been keeping a cone on her but as soon as it comes off she starts chewing her back.  So it must itch bad.  She needs some relief.FP, I hope you feel better.  I know how you feel about the politics.  I hope you both have a wonderful New Year.  Miranda, your ahead of us, yours maybe over.Take care both of you.Hugs, Karen...

Hi FP. Good to see you. I truly don't think I would care if I never saw Christmas again. It doesn't help that the buildup begins insanely early now, I swear much earlier than it did when I was a child. No sooner than Halloween is over, supermarkets are putting Christmas food on the shelves. The Christmas lights are switched on in mid November (the 17th in my town). The dreadful Christmas songs begins playing everywhere from mid to late November onwards. (It also peeves me that nobody plays carols anymore.) By the time mid December arrives, I'm just burnt out on all this stuff, as it feels like it's been going on for weeks already. Has been going on for weeks. And now I'm wondering if it is like this in America. Do you guys carry on like this or do you start your preparations later? Re anaemia. I never used to suffer from it - that's yet more collateral damage from the Crohn's. I could never tolerate oral iron in the past, not even the so-called gentle formulations. But oral iron tends to be poorly absorbed in IBD folks anyway. And in my case I don't seem to absorb it at all. I get an iron infusion and all my iron stores are gone in a few months. My haemoglobin is 10 at the moment, but in the past it has been 7 and once it was so low I had a blood infusion (I felt better straight away - it was like an infusion of pure energy).I am so sorry about your cousin from Birmingham - millions of us are in the same boat. Brexiters, of course, are in complete denial, but I've been worried about this for two years. I was *particularly* worried about my eyes, because without treatment the uveitis will cause irreversible damage which eventually will cause sight loss. And my uveitis has become chronic, so I need to take a daily dose of Maxidex. But I was lucky in one way: Maxidex is available OTC in Spain. So I asked my Brexit-voting, Spanish-residing aunt if she could bring me back some Maxidex and Levothyroxine from Spain, which fortunately she could (this is the same aunt whose house I went to a few days ago).By the way, the same aunt rushed off to get an Irish passport after she voted leave in the referendum. And every rich Brexiter supporter/campaigner is securing EU membership for themselves and their families on the quiet, although they can't keep it completely secret, otherwise I wouldn't know about it. Anyway, depending on what meds your cousin takes, she should look into seeing if she can get them from Spain or another EU country without a prescription. That won't be possible for most meds, obviously. But if she's got hypothyroidism, levothyroxine is one med you can get without a prescription. The transition period should last until December 2020 and I think Johnson will stick to it. He's lazy and doesn't want, I think, no deal chaos. (On the other hand, with his majority there is nothing to stop him from crashing out now, tbh.)Karen - Poor Luna! In a few years her need for exercise and to run about for hours should be less, but in the meantime I think behaviours like chasing her own tail stem from not having enough to do or being able to run around and burn off some of her nervous energy. Some breeds are not as high energy and are more apathetic (which includes many of the larger dogs), which would have been more suitable to you I think... :-/ I've no idea how scientific this list is. Not very I imagine, but I used to know a great dane and a bull mastiff. The great dane was placid and easy-going, whilst the bull mastiff never got up off the floor as far as I could tell: https://terriblyterrier.com/laziest-dog-breeds/*sees time* Oh crap. As always, I'm running late. And as always, a "short" post turned into a long one. Sorry about that guys >.> I'd better go now. Foot quite painful this morning (more so than when I got up yesterday), but ibuprofen has dulled the pain. Hope you all have a good New Year's Eve.

Hi Miranda,I have seriously thought about getting another dog to keep her company.  I thought another dog would take her mind off of her tail.  But if I did, I would most likely get a dog from a shelter.  She came as a gift from a breeder.  The problem though would be the expense of two dogs.  Just her alone costs me a small fortune.  But I just got her spayed on the 11th and that is a part of it that wont happen again.  But the dog food is expensive as I get for tummy and skin sensitivities.  And her treats.  It is always something I guess.  I have her on Coprophagia as she tends to like the taste of her poo.  Also on a powder for her skin and coat plus salmon bites for skin.  She does have a real shiny coat.  She is all black.Thanks for sharing the link.  I love dogs, even lazy ones.  This one is too high energy.  Hoping she grows out of it soon.Take care Miranda.Hugs, Karen...

Karen - I don't think Luna will "grow" out of being high energy, at least not for several years - until she reaches middle/old age for a dog basically. My aunt and uncle had a young male Boxer that they couldn't handle. They'd had Boxers before, two of them, a mum and a daughter, but they were younger then and in better health. I loved their dog, he was a sweetheart. But he needed more exercise and discipline than they could give him (he pulled my aunt over onto the ground once when she was walking him on the leash). Anyway, sadly my uncle died not long afterwards. My aunt decided she couldn't look after the dog on her own and took him to Boxer Rescue. He was rehomed and apparently he was very happy with his new home and owner. He was able to run about in fields, something that he couldn't do in a surburban bungalow with a small, neat garden. What I'm trying to say is, you don't have to keep a dog if it is not right for either you or the dog :/ A dog as beautiful as Luna (you showed us a pic of her once) would deffo find a new home quickly, so I don't think you would need worry about her languishing in a dog home for years. Anyway, it's *just* an idea.... But that would make it much easier and more affordable to get another dog who is quieter and happy to laze around all day. I hope you don't mind me suggesting it. Not much to report. I saw in the New Year with my mum and brother, but it's safe to say I didn't have a scintilla of hope then and I don't have one now. I miss those days when I could hope for a better world, even fleetingly. I have thought back a lot to 1999 and what a different world it seemed then, on the cusp of 2000. I didn't know it then, but that was the ending of my 'old' life and the start of my new, worse, one.

Hi Miranda,I guess I am hoping she grows out of the chasing of the tail.  Because she catches it and bites it when she does.  We are seriously thinking of having it amputated.  Because she wont let it heal.  But I am kind of waiting to see if she will stop.  Problem is they are pups until about 2 years old.  She is 16 months.  She is on antibiotics now for a skin infection.  She had just started chewing on her back and legs.  We just put new filters in the humidifier for her and run it on high..  We have had it running ever since it got cold enough to need heat.  That is when the chewing started.  When we had to start using heat.I am hoping in spring we can go back to walking every day.  I can't give up on her just yet.  The vet said if the itching doesn't stop, which it hasn't, we could try steroids.  I think she said prednisone or cortisone.  I can't remember now.  I guess that helps stop the itching..  I got her dog food for sensitive skin and stomach.  She hasn't been on it long.  She has a sensitive stomach too.  Poor dog.  I understand what you are saying Miranda.  I have to keep trying unless I see she is unhappy.  Then I would consider rehoming her.  I know though that the people I got her from would take her back so I wouldn't have to worry about finding a good home.  Thanks so much for your concern.  Thanks for posting.Hugs, Karen...

No problem, Karen. And thanks for not taking it the wrong way. I know that you would never be cruel to Luna in a million years, I am just concerned she is unintentionally suffering. That's why a couple of posts back I mentioned the possibility of getting a dog walker... They are fairly common where I am. If I lived near you I would take Luna out myself D: If it made no difference, then no harm has been done. But an hour of walking (preferably running around if you have a park, wood, etc. where dogs can freely run near you) would burn off some of that excess energy and calm her down a bit, I suspect. I remember our old Jack Russell terrier when he was young: he could chase a football for hours and not tire or get bored of it :/ If the chewing started when the heat began, I'm wondering if it's too hot for Luna, as she has that really thick coat. And dogs in general are more sensitive to the heat than humans are (they have a higher body temperature, plus a coat of fur that we lack). Could you turn the heat down without making yourself cold? Or give Luna an unheated room? (Sorta offtopic, but heating is so expensive I only heat one room at a time anyway. Electricity prices are insane in this country. Sorry. That deffo was offtopic.) Anyway, best of luck to you both. I suppose I had better get a (very very) late lunch now. Or else a light snack and wait until dinner, not sure which would be better at this point.

I called the vet office and asked about an allergy medication.  I am waiting for a call back.  There is someone who had the same problem with their dog that I have.  I feel I should give the medication a shot.  It is suppose to work fast too so I will know right away if it is allergies.  Thank you for your concern Miranda.  I wouldn't want her to be suffering either.  She is happy for the most part.  She is on antibiotics now.  I have ordered probiotics for her.  Pumpkin flavored.  I think she will like them.  Just waiting for them to arrive.  I ordered all of her favorite treats too.  I get from Chewy.  They are fair priced and deliver fast.  I am ready for lunch.  My tummy is growling as a matter of fact.  It is a little early but I didn't eat much for breakfast.  I hope you have a good rest of the day.  Thanks for posting back.Hugs, Karen...

I hope she enjoys the pumpkin-flavoured probiotics >.> Our dog used to love rawhide bones. He would chew on a bone longer than his head but would eventually get through it all. Good for teeth too. At least I never remember him having any dental issues and he lived until he was 16.Going to bed soon... I am trying a new experiment of leaving my phone in another room overnight, 'cos the smartphone is the most evil distraction device ever invented and I have no self control. Last night was encouraging: I actually picked up a book and I actually read it. 'Cos there was nothing else to do.
Good for you Miranda.  I notice when I play with my phone before bed, I have a harder time falling asleep.Hugs, Karen...

Why does 1am arrive every single night and I'm not remotely tired? It sucks to be a night owl.Guess what time it is now.... ? Goodnight! :p Not much to report really. I was at my mum's friend's house yesterday. My mum had a half price voucher for Chiquitos, so we went there and I ordered the most expensive mains course off the menu: the ultimate combo fajitas. I liked it, but my bowels didn't.... >.> Looking into getting a new pair of curtains for my bedroom, 'cos I want to brighten it up a bit. The curtains that are there now are a particularly grim and instituational shade of green. I want something colourful, with flowers 'n' stuff.

I use to go in streaks where I would stay up real late and barely sleep.  Not anymore though.  I am in bed way too early these days.Just popping in to say "hey"...I hope you find some curtains that you love.Hugs, Karen...

Nothing wrong with going to bed early. I wish I could feel tired earlier! Though I do feel quite tired right now, and it's "only" 11:30pm. I tried a new game tonight, Stardew Valley. It's a highly-praised farming game, which is meant to be super-duper relaxing and chill - I ended up nearly punching my laptop screen out >_>. To be fair, it does look lovely. But the keyboard controls are really fiddly and annoying, and your character's energy runs out too quickly for you to get much done. On top of that, the inventory filled up really quickly, meaning you can't pick up anything new. That's when I lost my temper, trying to buy a backpack I couldn't afford and ending up with about 50 beans instead (don't ask). The game froze at that point and I had to bring up Windows Explorer to exit it. So yeah. I might just go back to Minesweeper... >.>

postContent.comment: Here is Paul's last post on the other thread.  Happy New Decade to everyone!Mine starts with a colonoscopy, which is no fun if anyone here has had the misfortune of going through one. Not the actual procedure, which is done under sedation, but rather the low-fiber and eventually liquid-only diet followed by the final purging process (at the risk of TMI).SWMMDD+PDD

Paul I empathize and wish you in this processAnother day on codeine so can't post stuff.  my speacill weed blue silver tip for migraines is not working todaythis will pass as it always doeshave a wonderful day allPeaceTrina
I hate the prep for colonoscopies.  I am probably due to have another one.  I had one about five years ago.  I didn't fall asleep so I watched mine on the screen.  Trippy.Hugs, Karen...

I did a number of different things today, including seeing my psychiatrist at a local community health center.  I see  him once every two months.We had a good talk.He's happy with the progress I've made over the years.  And I am too.
That's great Mike, It always feels good when they are happy with our progress.  I am glad you had a good session.  I go back in February.Hugs, Karen...
Thanks, Karen!This morning I didn't go out anywhere because it was snowing here.  But now in the early afternoon it has stopped and we even have a little bit of blue skies.
Hi. Good one mike. Hi karen...trendy and all. HT
Today I didn't have as much work to do at the library as I usually do.  But it was still worth going there.
Hi. HT,

Hi Jamie,Hi Mike,It is nice to see both of you post.  It is sunny here today.  But we are suppose to get a foot of snow tomorrow night.  I guess there is going to be a lot of weather activity in the US in the next few days.  I hope you both have a good day/night.Hugs, Karen...
Karen, pace yourself while shoveling the snow.

Hi all, Paul, i hope all went well with your procedure. NJ 65 degrees today.. gotta love itPerhaps we will get on HTs schedule and have snow in July!Great therapy session today, his suggestion to start every 2 weeks again, I am so proud. I hardly write anything in my journal anymore, well the one he sees🙄Therapists cant know everything! Right!?.  Not anymore,  taking my life back. PSYCHOLOGY FACTS:One thing that has been shown to consistently combat anger is humor. Not only do most people enjoy humor, but it break the attention and stress caused by feeling angry and refocuses it on something less physiologically taxing.FUN FACT:  [🤣 has to be the beginning of "obnoxious American tourists"!]Jefferson and John Adams paid a visit to William Shakespeare's home in Stratford-upon-Avon in 1786. There, they chipped off a piece from Shakespeare's chair as a souvenir.

We got snow last night but not as much as we were suppose to.  We were right on the edge of the storm.  Yay...Trina that is awesome about your sessions.  I am happy for you.  It is always nice to know we are progressing.  Mike, I didn't have to shovel.  We do have a snow blower which helps.Oh and Trina thank you for the facts.  Interesting.Hugs you all.HT probably sleeping right now.  Hugs to you too.Karen...

I had a bad few days, triggered by taking my mother in law to the doctor (major undertaking physically and time wise for me) and continuing the process of taking apart and moving the king sized water bed that my husband loved and I hated.  Both brought up long seated anger and this always makes me depressed.  I feel better now, the bed is out of the room and I have ordered a new bed and comforter - not second hand.  My husband used to come home in the winter but not this year.   I am staying married to him because at this point it's just easier.  Off to work for three days tomorrow,  I look forward to getting away.Kathy

Awe Kathy,I am sorry you had bad days.  I am glad you are feeling better now.  It is something when work seems like a vacation.  But that happens from time to time.I hope you get your new bed and comforter soon.  Hang in there.Hugs, Karen...

author: MainerMikeBrown
title: I Didn't Think I Had Any Irrational Beliefs

postContent.comment: Back in 2000, I finally decided to get help for my issues with depression and anger.Just before going into therapy, I wondered what any counselor was going to be able to say to me that would make me start feeling happier and less angry.  The reason was because I didn't think I had any irrational beliefs.But man was I wrong!  As soon as I started seeing a shrink, I quickly found out that I had a lot of irrational beliefs.When I went into therapy, I learned that I couldn't help the world as much as I thought I could at the time.  I also found out that it's better to be assertive with rude people than to be aggressive or passive.So if you're thinking of seeing a counselor who specializes in Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) for the first time, you must realize that you likely do have at least some irrational beliefs.  And a good CBT therapist can help you replace unhealthy, irrational beliefs with more healthy, rational beliefs over time.Post Edited (MainerMikeBrown) : 1/6/2020 6:24:08 PM (GMT-7)
Thanks for posting Mike, all true.PeaceTrina
Best not see a therapist who specializes in cbt!!! Lol. HT.Not a fan of the behaviorist methods of cbt.

author: getting by
title: Daily Check In Thread for all...  #190

postContent.comment: Good morning everybody,Here is Kathy's post from the last thread.  I hope you all survived Thanksgiving.  On the way to Christmas now...No turkey for us this time. I didn't want to make the whole dinner for just my son and I and I don't know how I would puree turkey for my mother in law. So we had steak and she had other pureed stuff. I did make a pumpkin pie.My son left this morning and the interstate was closed for most of the day so I was stuck in town. I thought about re-organizing the pantry shelves but my trash hasn't been picked up for over a week and I have no place to put new trash, so that wouldn't work.Still very depressed and stressed.Double Depression (dysthymia with intermittent MDD), Pre-diabetes, osteoarthritis both hips with replacements 3/1/2017 and 1/8/2019

KathySo sorry you are depressed and stressed.  The holidays are hard for so many people,  the Waltons just do not exist. Try to do something that make you feel good, or relaxed.  When I real depressed, I listen to smooth jazz and work on a jigsaw puzzle.  It does help me. This thanksgiving I spent alone with my dog.  I could have asked at least one "friend" more of an aquiantance over.  But I did not feel like cooking. It was enough that I did have to pretend John and I were still together for his Mother and cousin.  We did have an arguement over the phone and via text,  over the lawn care.  In reality it was about him taking responsibility, he lives with his mom 3 mins away by car, and he wants me to text him when the yard needs tending.and he will schedule it into his calendar!Bullcrap, he gets home in plenty of time to do it in the late afternoon.   I refuse to do this, be his, whatever.   I will just have things taken care and not bother him.  So much easierPeace Trina

Since we miss Joyce so much, I have decided to post some "facts" often.I have Psychology facts downloaded on my phone, so one will be from there.   The other will be random information.HT the numbers do not work anymore to enlarge text, or I would have. FYIMy hope is all will enjoy them. "Psy. Fact: Have you ever gone to sleep feeling sad or anxious, and woke up feeling in a much better mood the next morning?  That is because when your brain goes into 'REM' sleep, it releases chemicals that erase the mental pain of traumatic experiences. "SneezingPeople say "God bless you" when you sneeze because this was often the first sign of plague in medieval times. So you are basically, saying "Well, I hope you don't die of that!"PeaceTrina

Cool Trina, I miss Joyce too.  I am glad you are going to do this.  Very interesting.  They are probably also thinking "I hope you aren't contagious".  LOL...I am glad you are putting your foot down.Kathy,I am sorry you are feeling depressed.  I agree with Trina, do something nice for yourself.  We deserve that from time to time.  Self nurturing is difficult to do sometimes  when you are depressed.  So push extra hard...Hugs, Karen...Oh and one holiday down, two more to go...  The big one is next...

Thanks everyone.  I feel a little better today.  I was going to stay in again today because we are having a big windstorm (that is still going) but I knew I'd feel better if I went out and I don't mind driving in bad weather.  So I went to the next county over and did a little shopping and had lunch.  I anticipated getting stuck in ski traffic on the way back so I had a snack available and listened to an audio book.  I am going to try to do a little crocheting later, because that is always calming.
Keep strong friends. HT

Hi all.My kids are driving me nuts.  Son won't respond to daughter's texts about her car.  I message him and ask him to please help her.  Neither one has updated me in over 24 hrs.  No idea if he was able to help her get her car fixed.  I'm forcing myself not to ask.Had a nice 3 day weekend with my partner.  We did a bunch of shopping...none of it for the holidays!  We did, however, find a nice new seat for me to use in my office!  It's on wheels and takes up much less space than the chair I had bought at the thrift shop and has excellent lumbar support for my aching back.  My t.e.n.s. unit is still m.i.a.Rainy, windy here...yuck.  But, at least it's not snow, although I did bring the shovel in, just in case.  Sunday evenings are tough for me after she leaves.  Have had my cocoa...almost time to put my jammies on and slide into bed.  Wishing everyone peace.

aaahhh. crocheting,  yes it is calming.  Though reading is much more calming for me.  It has always been an escape.It is hard for me to just sit and watch TV without doing something else.  It makes me nervous.  This is from my childhood.  Empty hands and all that. Siblings,  disagreements are life long I think.  I hope they got together and the car was fixed.Shopping, this year I only have a couple friends, one has been mailed and recv'd already.  And something for my mother in law.  I already bought.So I will spend $$ on toys for tots this year.  Fun stuff.  Already spent over $300.00 over the course of the year on Covent House.I am hoping everyone is safe from the storms, the fires, and the floods.  Jamie, I saw that Aussie has wildfires, so sorry to hear that.  Here are todays did bits.PYSCH: MUSIC, "Listening to 5 - 10 songs a day CAN improve memory, strengthen immune systems and reduce depression by 80%."SNOW: Nova Scotia holds the record for the most "snow angels" ever made simultaneously in multiple locations.  In 2011,  22,022 Nova Scotia residents in 130 separate locations all plopped down in the snow to make snow angels.One more tid bit.  I highly recommend the book 'The Other Wise Man'. You can find it free on the web. It is 138 pages.  The first 2 pages are worth pushing through.  Peace and comfort every one. Trina

I'm on a psychiatric medication called Clozaril, which requires me to get a blood test once per month at a nearby community health center.I don't like needles.  But I don't get real panicky when the phlebotomist draws blood from me each month either.This morning I got the blood test for the month out of the way.  And now I'm just on the computer this afternoon waiting for the snowstorm to arrive.

Thanksgiving thru Christmas is always a difficult part of the year for me.  Weather, short daylight hours, general busy-ness and grumpiness, .... blah.Hanging in there but disgusted that my hip is bothering me yet again.  This year my dentist, my GP, my hip Dr, and my chiropractor all retired!! All I have left is my rheumy and he can't solve everything.Will do my best to start making calls tomorrow to find a new hip Dr.  Last time (4 yrs?) it was bursitis which PT didn't help, but then a cortisone shot helped.  Earlier this year I had 5 months of physical therapy which did help... but need a new doc to say if this is bursitis or if I've developed some other horrid malady.Also disgusted that I can't loose my 40 lbs of prednisone weight.  I lost about 20 of it earlier in the year, then gained 10 back.  Trying to talk myself into 28 days of a strict keto diet to shake things up.  In general, I don't think keto is all that healthy so will not do longer than 28 days, no matter what.  I'm sure loosing a bit more weight will help my hip, even thought by BMI measures I'm not in the "obese" range.  First world problems, all.  I have a roof over my head, food to eat, and am not being chased or actively persecuted by anyone.  Thankful!

ugggh prednisone weight is the worst.I just finished a burst pack- they are not bad like long term daily prednisone use.I don't think I've ever lost that weight from those days. I'm 10 pounds heavier than I should be and nothing budges it. I give up and try not to take prednisone trading pain for additional weight.I lost my GP and Rhuemy in 2017- devastating. However both are replaced now and all is well.your keto routine is maybe why you keep gaining back. My son lost 50 lbs on it but if he doesn't stay strict he feels sick and then gains back weight quickly. I don't think I like the diet health wise but people swear by it.Personally....no bread, crackers, sweets- I can't live like that. They're the only keeping me alive with my sadness of losing my son.Which, since I'm on the daily thread, is getting worse with every day Christmas gets closer.  It was just so senseless. Last night the global grief group I belong to did a candle lighting at 7 pm for all our deceased children all over the world. There were no local gatherings so I lit my candle in front of his picture here. My husband didn't see the point so he went to bed. He can't stay up past 6 or so- he's done trying to live in this world without his son by that hour. I know how he feels- I don't stay up much later.
Today I ate a chicken patty sandwich at a local general store, and it was quite tasty!  I had a can of Dr. Pepper to go along with it.I enjoy going out to eat at lunchtime.
Depressive fatigue and general fatigue has caught up with with me.Such is life. HT

Where are my manners?  I should not have left everyone hanging on what is going on with daughters' car...it was the gas cap!  She could use a tune up as well, but replacing the cap has it running well enough for now.  Hopefully over school break she can get it to the shop for the other work.Half of the lights I have on the house for the holidays are not working.  I didn't bother to put anything else up outside this year.  What goes up must come down...and I'm just not into it this year.  I'd rather use my energy inside.  So, half lights it is!  Most people here in the trailer park don't put anything up, so I'm still ahead of the game!Rearranged the furniture in the living room for the winter.  Now, both heat ducts are not covered and I've created a little 'dining area' behind the couch for the drop leafed table and the 2 chairs.  So happy I can use my table cloths again!  I bought shelf brackets so I can put a 6ft shelf up over the t.v. for my ever changing artwork/decor displays.  The brackets match the ones in the kitchen, only those are silver and the ones for the living room are white.  Continuity is key when you can see both spaces at once.Lisa brought my Nativity set down.  I'd sent it up with her before hurricane Sandy, for safe keeping.  Then, when my daughter moved back in with me, her cats were notorious climbers, so I didn't want to risk putting it up around them.  They've mellowed a bit, so I'm seeing how it goes this year.  WOW...as I write this...Lucky has climbed up and is wending his way around the figurines!  Be still my heart!  I'm so afraid they'll be broken!The house is really coming together nicely.  The bulk of the work is done...little details and finishing touches are pretty much all that is left for now.  I can't do major repair work until warmer weather comes along, so I'll just try to enjoy the way things are for now.  One more curtain rod, a rack of hooks for jackets, hanging a picture or two and the shelf in the living room are pretty much all there is.  I'll be getting a new lamp for the living room...I cleaned the old one and now the top light hums...so I don't use it!I've started another amaryllis...Minerva...red with white streaks...and a pot of paper whites.  Lisa bought me a white Christmas cactus, too!  These should help me get through winter, I hope!  I put fresh suet out for the birds but I don't think they've found it yet.Hoping peace for everyone!

Thoughts:Psychology fact:"If you combine orange and yellow on your coloring page, you may experience some positive changes in your mood. Keep on mixing these colors and you should definitely feel the effect of mood improvement. "This fun fact leaves no mystery to the snobby character of "Charles" on the series MASH! The Puritan Grinches who Banned ChristmasIn 1645, the puritans of England removed Christmas as a national holiday. In 1659, puritans of New England took their anti-Christmas fervour a step further, banning Christmas celebrations entirely. Contravention of this law incurred a penalty of five shillings, and included any person avoiding work or feasting.This ban persisted for decades. Indeed, Cotton Mather, an influential New England church leader, railed against the merrymaking so common to Christmas, saying, "I hear of a Number of young People of both Sexes belonging, many of them, to my Flock, who have had on the Christmas night, this last week, a Frolick, a revelling Feast, and Ball, which discovers their Corruption, and has a Tendency to corrupt them yet more."The ban persisted for centuries, with some parts of Boston keeping churches closed as late as the 1930s.Peace AllTrina

Happy Old Year everybody!  I can't pin my hopes on some other time, I must stay in today.Had a 'good' Christmas.  Made a beef stew so people could just dish some up whenever they were hungry, rather than set a time that might not mesh with their eating schedules.  My Mom used to buy cold cuts and rolls for Christmas so we could make our own sandwiches whenever we wanted to eat.  Same principle I guess.Lisa and her Mom will be coming down today so we can all go out to lunch.  In the past, I'd go up to them and we'd go out to dinner and I'd stay over but, now that I live alone there is no-one to care for the dogs (pit bulls, so no-one else is willing and I can't blame them).  Once they've gone back home, I'll be in my jammies, sipping got cocoa and waiting for the idiot neighbors to set off their fireworks, as they do every year, and giving the dogs their new knuckle bones to try to distract them from the noise.  Otherwise, they'll be barking their heads off!No 'resolutions' for me.  Why set myself up for failure? ha ha!  So much has changed already, and I know more changes are coming as it is!Going for a second opinion with an oral surgeon today.  I know the torus must be removed from the upper palate before I can have dentures made but...the first surgeon said he can only do local anesthesia and I cannot imagine someone using a hammer and chisel and a grinder on the roof of my mouth with me wide awake and fully aware!  So, this consultation is more about knocking me out for the procedure than it is about alternatives to removal per se.I'm also hoping this one will say the upper teeth can be removed at the same time.  One molar has been getting infected and the canine on the other side is loose and constantly painful.  I'd rather not leave them until the torus site is healed, at least another month!I'll be stocking up on soft foods and liquid meal replacements ahead of having the procedures.  I'll probably get some Benefiber or Fibercon, too as I don't think liquids will make me feel full and I don't want issues 'down below' either!Being toothless will be temporary, I know.  Still, I'm trying to prepare my ego for the blow.  I need this dentist to understand that I want to see MY smile...not someone else's idea of what my new teeth should look like.  Even after orthodontia, I never had perfectly straight teeth.  I'm a coffee drinker and a smoker, so they've never been really white either.  I'm having more anxiety over how I'll look, more than anything else!

Hi Pitmom, and Happy old and new year to you!I got dentures (top) in my 30's but got immediate denture.  I didn't have to be hammered and chiseled though.  So you probably need time to heal.  Hopefully seeing an oral surgeon, they will knock you out.  I am sure that would be best for the procedure.  I was glad I got the denture as I always had bad teeth.  I am sure you will look nice in your dentures.  Especially if you replicate your natural teeth.  One day at a time, as you don't want anxiety about it.  I think you will be happy once it is all over with.Hang in there Pitmom, and again have a good transfer into 2020.PS the beef stew sounded good.  I am making home made spaghetti sauce today.Hugs, Karen...
