You said you are on 300mg daily for years, that is scary. Why would one need such high dose for years?I have depression/major depressive disorder for the last 5 years. Undiagnosed and untreated. I just started the treatment 3 weeks back. Also taking SNRI for serotonin and norepinephrine. My mood is good, and subtle improvement in norepinephrine memory attention sharpness. My arousals and desires, engagement in desires, deriving pleasures those functionalities are dead. That is the main problem.  I guess depression of many years changes/lowers the receptors in the brain. Taking Tyrosine and other supplements does not help. Bupropion is a receptor agonist, I wonder how long it takes to restore normal receptor density and activity. What do you think of this?

I have dysthymia, which is chronic depression, which started in childhood. I do have episodes of major depression but it is still different than classic major depressive disorder.  It is not going to go away, sort of like any other chronic disease.  300 mg of bupropion is the most common dose, 450mg per day is the maximum dose.  I have not suffered any consequences from being on this for the last 17 years.  Bupropion is also one of the few antidepressants with few to no side effects regarding intimate relations.Depression is a multifactorial disease: it doesn't have one specific cause. The reasons for a decrease in the neurotransmitters is not specifically known.  There is a decrease in the specific receptors in the brains of people with depression and I don't know if that can be reversed.  The question is sort of like the "chicken and the egg" - which came first - the depression or the decreased transmitters?  That is why medical treatment focuses on increasing the amount of neurotransmitter available by blocking it's reuptake and sort of flooding the remaining receptors. Many people with major depression do recover and only take antidepressants for months rather than years. So take heart.  And also remember, that since depression is a multifactorial disease, it has other treatments that are just as effective as medication (especially when used in combination) such as talk therapy and exercise)  I strongly suggest that you do one or both of these also.I hope this helps and wasn't too preachy.  Each one of us is different and treatment needs to be tailored specifically for you, so work closely with your provider and don't give up hope.  And feel free to keep asking questions.  If I can't answer them, at least I can commiserate.
I had to take a high dose of Wellbutrin too.   300mg.  But the side effects at a high dose was more than I could bear.  So I switched to Effexor and then to Pristiq.Hugs, Karen...

Duloxetine/Cymbalta works on norepinephrine and serotonin, so you could consider that. My experience of duloxetine is that it worked better than SSRIs - at least for the first few months. Sadly after that my brain habituated to it and the depression and negative thoughts came back. After that, it was useless. So annoying that nothing seems to work long term for me.
Be careful with Cymbalta   notorious for wiping out your REM sleep. I found out by having a sleep study, which all patients should have to r/o that as a cause of Depression.

Yes studies are being done that highlight sleep issues that are causive of depression conditions. Just went to a seminar on mental illness and sleep.Sleep apnea is anorher causive element to a depressive condition or illness. No sleep no body healing and the rest of it is scientifically known.These are either separate or tend to be protagonists in regards to a depressive diagnosis. Many aspects or reasons to a dx...and sometimes there's none.With sleep disturbance apnea etc the likelyhood of a depressive condition is far more apparent....just in terms of rhe above...not in general.HT

As Wimbledon pops around soon i take a moment and remember joyce. Am sure she will be delighted with ash barty.To my tour buddies' the 🐢 will be disturbing his scattered sleep to not miss much. Bring on le tour. HT
Thanks for remembering Joyce (PA Grandma).  She is dearly missed.Enjoy Wimbledon...  Hugs, Karen...

Hi everyone. I need some advice and frankly I don't have anyone to talk to very comfortably and it has been on my mind for a while now so... here goes nothing! I have a boyfriend of a different race and religion for a few years and when we first started frankly he wasn't very good to me. He was very unwelcoming when I came over to his place, every cent counts when it comes to bills whether it's for food etc, always wanted me to shut my mouth around his parents. But for some reason I stuck around like glue, which I admit is very stupid of me. I confronted him and he started acknowledging and started to change until recently he thought it was fine to go out with his friends constantly, who nearly always talks bad of me. They always say things like 'oh why is she so clingy' or 'don't you want to find some other girl?' But they pretend to be nice towards me. I was super offended and confronted him, but the first thing he did was argue and tried to convince me that I was just overreacting and that he just wanted to go out and have fun with his buddies. It took 2 nights of my anger for him to realize. Now, he seems really regretful of all the things he has done and really is keen to change. But my family is also rather conservative thus the differing race and religion is a real issue as well. Needless to say, my family is quite discouraging. I've talked to him about religion and he said he's willing to convert for my sake once marriage rolls around, though I'm so afraid that he would change his mind when we're too far into our relationship. I'm so afraid that after marriage, he would change. Or if he can't live up to his words. Yet, there's something in me that keeps on coming back to him. Like the way we are able to share everything to each other, which nobody else has that sort of relationship with me. So I'm just walking in the dark, and in fear. Please, I need advice. What should I do? Should I break up with him for my family's sake? Should I continue this relationship even if I keep on losing faith and trust? I'm so confused. Thank you for helping.

Wow...  I don't like him treating you bad.  Are you sure he wont go back to that?  If you are serious about marriage, I would give it a long engagement.  I think you need to get to know him better.  It doesn't sound like you been together a real long time.  With differences in culture there is going to be a lot of give and take honestly.  You two have to compromise.  I am not trying to scare you away from him.  I know you will do what is in your heart.  People do seem to change after marriage.  I don't know why.  My husband and I have been together for 18 years and friends for years before that.  I still find things new about him. Some I like, some I don't.  So tread lightly and pay attention.  Take it one day at a time, and don't rush into anything.  Like I say it is give and take.  When he is with his friends find things to do that you enjoy.  You don't want to get in between him and his friends.  He will grow to resent you if you do.  Talk to him calmly maybe about limiting some of his time.  But don't expect him to let his life revolve around you.  It is like you kind of do your own thing and then meet in the middle. . Share responsibilities.  There is so much to marriage, but you should take it one day at a time.  Don't rush into anything.I wish you the best.Hugs, Karen...

Basic principles.If a relationship is to much work, just to get along, it is not the life long union.If you are talked down to now [verbal abuse]What will you be willing to put up with after the marriage?If GF/BF is not standing up for one another when "friends" berate mate, there is no trust.When you marry,  how do want your relationship to serve you?PeaceTrina
I feel further growth is needed along with greater maturity. What you see now is a small amount of your future reality that will either get better or worse. I fear the latter. HT

author: BrianJ (bne)
title: beside myself....first time since last time.....2008-9

postContent.comment: I haven't been here in a very long time but need to talk to someone....anyone....I am bipolar and suffer major depression. Stopped bipolar meds 2+ yrs ago but still on anti-D's. Last 2 days have been real hard. my youngest Son is with me now - 27 yrs Asperger's/Autism - and drinking too much. Huffing ether as well although I stepped down hard and stopped that. I work 12 hr shifts as a Mainframe Analyst for our provincial government and due to cut-backs, have been working an additional 12-36 hrs per month since last Dec. The stress of my job can often seem overwhelming but after 35 yrs I am strong in my position and always confident in my decisions. But I fear am burning out. I took a week in the bush recently and it was wonderful but it took me 5 days just to unwind and get the world out of my mind. When I returned I had 2 days to get ready for 7 shifts straight. I am now 3 days into this shift and that last 2 nights I've just cried and cried til everything hurts. I feel I have been such a failure as a Father - there is considerable history behind this statement - but I DO know I did the best I could with what I had. I hate this crap of desperately trying to hold it together til ya get home. I have had 2 'breakdowns' since '96 and I know the feeling of it's coming. Tourette's sufferers will know what I mean. If I can make it thru the next 4 shifts, I have 4 days off and am sure I can use my tool kit to dig outa this rut.I really needed to vent Folks - thanks to all who took the time to read me rant. I may only cry once more tonight....maybe not at all.I have never made a long-term commitment to this site but to those who have - Thank You so Very Much! I know the time and emotion that goes into this type of endeavour and if it weren't for you Folks I'd be in a much uglier place.Brian

Hey mate.  You have done and are doing ya best.  Your self care is paramount.  The turtle sends ya strength.  Are there any community supports out there to help you and your son?  Big brother program?Keep posting for support. HT

Thanks Brother, I needed someone to answer. I'm takin him to AA next week. I've been thru this fekkin ringer before - just hate it. I gotta feelin a lot of this is has been buildin up and I'm just finally lettin go.At 59 I have no compunctions about cryin but ya still hold it, y'know. BS spartan male upbringing. Anyhow, I know I gotta tend to ME. Ain't no one else gonna.Brianp.s. funny how yer language can change when yer honest
Yep.  Let it out. My go to is tunes and associated metallic screaming! Yep metal head. Spiked shell!! Stuff the spartan code...you need to let it out mate. Pop in later. HT.

Hi Brian,So sorry for what you are going through.  I am glad you are taking your son to AA.  That should help.  Huffing is no good for the brain.  I am glad you put a stop to him doing that.  I hope you can hang in there.  Keep posting as it helps.  Know we are all here for you.Hugs, Karen...

Thanks Karen and HT. I like the idea of metal....listened to Bobaflex today.....it does help. And yeah...stuff the spartan crape. Half way thru today's shift and alone all day is helping. Work is a good distraction but being alone I can zip out fer a weep if I need or even scream right at my desk. Just gotta keep from slammin the keyboard...LOL.What makes this situation the worst is having no one to talk to. That's why I'm here - this site has helped me before. Funny how just getting crap out can make things seem so ... insignificant. I stepped outside a while ago into a gorgeously sunny day and let the breeze blow away last night's cobwebs. At least over the years I've recognised that all sorrows ease or pass. I try to explain this to my Son but at his age (27) they only see what's behind them....not the light of the new day.Well, back to work and thanks again Folks. I will be back....Brian

Hi BrianJ (bne),It sounds like you are feeling a bit better.  I am glad.  Sometimes being right in the middle of situation makes it hard to see the light.  But if we keep pushing forward we eventually see it.  Often the light of a fresh new day makes things seem easier.  I know it is hard and for your son too.  He doesn't have the years of experience you have.  But he will get there.It is difficult if you don't have anyone to talk to.  I can't seem to tell people my problems though in person but I can sort of talk here.  And yes, just getting it down or getting it out helps.  I find writing things down helps me find perspective of a situation.  I just worry somebody will read it.  But sharing here, people seem to understand.I hope you have a good rest of the weekend and a Happy Memorial Day.Hugs, Karen...

Karen,thanks. Things are better. I've been trying so hard to stay on an even keel for my Son that I hadn't allowed myself to feel and acknowledge my low swing. Being Bipolar, I see it when it starts and can nearly always work through it - which means letting myself 'break down' and cry. I'm sure many here know the kind of cry I speak of - the entire body-wracking sobs that leave you completely drained. It almost always works, along with getting moving and fresh air.So I figure that's what was at the root of it all - although my Son's issues certainly exacerbated it. Anyhow, now on my 6th shift of 7 (nights now) and doin alright. It's his birthday this weekend so we're goin to his Mom's and I'll have a chance to catch up with my older Son. Looking forward to it!Thanks Again!Brian

Brian, I can so relate!  My daughter od'd in her bedroom and was revived with 2 doses of Narcan.  My brain knows I'm not a failure but those thoughts just don't stop coming!You said you were taking your son to AA...but what about YOU?  Have you considered Al-Anon?  I know your schedule doesn't leave much room but if you can get to a couple of meetings, get phone numbers and some literature...I think it would really help.

Yes Brian,We have to take care of ourselves through everything else.  I am glad you are feeling better.  I am glad you will get to see your other son too.  I hope it all goes well.You are going through a lot, but you are keeping your head above water and that is great.Let us know how it goes with your sons and their mother.Have a great day...Hugs, Karen...

Hi Brian Just wanted to check in and welcome you.Wish you the best with your son.   You have gotten the best from the best!No guilt trips now, when GT rises, challenge it with the knowledge that your son, has free choice.  find good in fact that he is reaching out for help.  And from where I stand your are a good example of a father.  Non of us are perfect, do best we can with what we have at the time.   Breathe through it, slow and easy,  you will make it.  We are here for you.PEACE AND STRENGTHTrina

Thank you All very much. I have been thru a couple of 12 step programs myself so have many tools and experience to draw on. I know I am too hard on myself sometimes but when it's yer kid at issue, you can't help feeling somehow responsible - regardless of their age. That said, I won't take on what's not mine. I was once the 'people pleaser'....the 'rescuer' and that just wears you down, keeping you from seeing what you yourself need.  That is not me anymore.Thankfully, my Ex and I have always agreed to raise our kids together and in love so I am not alone in this struggle. I am looking forward to this weekend - especially to see my eldest. He and his brother had a very serious physical confrontation a year back so don't talk but they each know that I will not choose one over the other and maintain a relationship with both of them. They also know that if they can't accept that, they can take a hike. As I said, I am NOT the people pleaser any longer.Anyhow, thanks so much folks....every time I post here I get more out and feel better. I'll check in next week.Brian
I hope you have a good time with your son Brian.  I am glad you and your ex are in this together.  It sounds like you have a good source of support.Have a good week.Hugs, Karen...

I am starting this thread with Beuna's last post...I've had a very up and down day. Most of the day I felt like I was doing my downward spiral into depression. I tried all the things I could think of - I sang in choir this morning, but I got teary eyed about the sermon. I went to the thrift store, which always lifts my mood, but towards the end I got unexpected news about my taxes that made my spirits sink. I went home and decided to take the dog to the dog park. I forgot about the recent snow and the dog park was too wet to use. Home I went and took a nap. Then I thought I would go to the rec center and do a little exercise to help my mood. It is about a 20 minute drive. I got there at 5:30 but when I signed in I was informed they were closing at 6:00 - Sunday you know. So I got a diet coke and a car wash instead. I feel a little better now after a nice phone call with my brother. Hopefully I'll stay this way.
Sorry I missed this, here is JamiI get the 💯, lol.Fp birthday happiness. To all having a hard time, know we are all thinking of yas.Trendy, I like poignant, spot on.e's last post also...

Having some mood swings and feel my anxiety coming again. I hate being on this emotional rollercoaster. One minute I'm good, the next I feel down.I'm hoping that the combo of therapy and eventually meds help.

Try some breathing exercises and meditation.  Both help the mood.  I breathe in through the nose and out through the mouth.  It is called smelling the roses and blowing out the candles.  It stops any anxiety that may be occurring.  Learn meditation.  It puts you in the moment.  And blocks other stuff out.  I have been practicing for many years.  I use it to get me to sleep at night, otherwise I would be thinking of everything on earth.  I hope this helps until your therapy and medications.I  hope you have a good day.Hugs, Karen...
Kathy,I hope that today is a better day.  Actually sunny here but not real warm yet.  But the snow we got last night is melting.  Yay!!!Take care and have a good day...Hugs, Karen...Hello Jamie!!!

I feel better today.  Being at work gives me no time to ruminate.  I made some decisions about my job - keep it, and the dog - keep her.  I paid my taxes and feel better just having done that also.  And I bought a killer lampshade at the thrift store after work that I don't really need, but it had fringe and was only 2.99 so what could I do?  I'll have a place to put it in my Utah house.

I'm glad to hear you're feeling better, Buena! And I'm sorry you've been on such an emotional roller coaster, FP. Breathing exercises and meditation like GB said are definitely helpful things. You might also want to consider taking a walk. Even just a short 30 minute walk can do uplifting things to your mood. I used to have a mood tracker app, and I noticed a very strong connection between my walks and a boosted mood. For me, checking in, it's been a terrible Monday. I went to the Health and Human services office. They were basically unhelpful. I went to the SSI office. Also unhelpful. Trying to figure these things out is difficult. Made a doctor appointment so I could try and discuss things with my doctor, had to cancel it much later same day because my car broke down.Had to go to work. Work was lousy and stressful and I nearly had an emotional breakdown. Walked home. I think the walk has helped me de-stress a bit. I don't feel all doom and gloom. But it's also, y'know, it's a lot to deal with right now especially while also trying to manage a Crohn's flare.

Hi Kathy,Hi Celey,I am glad you feel better Kathy.  I am glad you decided to keep the dog and your job.  Also I know how good it feels to pay the taxes.  Mine come up in June.  Celey, I am sorry that you had a terrible Monday.  I hope Tuesday is better.  I go to therapy today which is cool.  But it is a long drive there and back...I hope you both have a good day.  Take care...Hugs, Karen...

I was supposed to start a diet and exercise program today, but I have absolutely no motivation to do anything.My depression seems to come in wave lately. I think I'm going to force myself to walk home today. Maybe some sunlight would do me good.

I hope you walked.  It helps me in so many ways.  I had therapy today.  It went okay.  The drive is an hour each way and it tires me out.  I am glad it is over.  I didn't get to walk today but I did yesterday.  And I hope to tomorrow.Just sitting here listening to music..  It always makes me feel better.Have a good evening FP...Hugs, Karen...

FP - my therapist once told me when I was having trouble motivating to go exercise - " your brain can't do it, but your feet can."  So when I get that way I literally concentrate on my feet - putting my shoes on, picturing them walking out the door, etc, and it has been helpful.  I think you should work on one thing at a time, though.  Maybe trying to do both diet and exercise at the same time is too much.  Waling home is an excellent idea, because there is a tangible goal at the end.  Keep on truckin', as us oldsters say!

I've been fighting a losing battle with my depression for the past few weeks now. Aside from my rapidly deteriorating mental health I've been dealing more car troubles, I'm now looking for a new vehicle for the second time within a month since the guy who sold us my last vehicle didn't tell us that it couldn't be legally registered. the whole deal was pretty shaddy so we convinced the guy to take the vehicle back and return our money.
Dreams of anew,The day remains....Shadows fade,Dusk ascends;May the dreams of life....Rise anew with dawns light.HT

I am sorry you are struggling with your depression, Constant, but I am glad you got your money back for that car.We had a weird day here in Colorado.  You probably all know about the girl from Florida who came out here after making threats about shootings, bought a gun, etc.  Well, she wound up driving right past our high school and elementary school before going up to the mountain lake where they found her - in our county.  Very scary, but our schools were closed as well as the ones down in Denver.  I will be happy when the Columbine anniversary is behind us, and I don't even have kids in school anymore.

That is sad about the woman they found in Colorado.  But it doesn't sound like she was up to any good.  I don't know, I didn't see it all.  I am just glad the children are safe now.I hope you all have a good day...Raining here.Hugs, Karen...

Had to take my daughter to the ER again...this time they think she either tore her meniscus or ACL.  I know she can't help it...this is all comorbidities from Cushing's Disease...but I'm tired.  All it means for me is that she won't be any help to me...which is pretty much 'normal'.  Everyone seems to 'forget' that I am disabled...over doing is very bad for me.Before we left for the hospital, I had to eat something.  I told my grandson that the dogs had to go out as I went to the fridge to get a yogurt.  He said 'Uh-huh' but didn't move.  So, I waited a minute as a shoved the spoon into my mouth...then, I got up and went down the hall, yogurt cup in hand, to let the dogs out!  Only then did his mother speak up.I know this sounds like self pity...another thing I must do for myself! ha haI had plans this weekend...that now must be changed.  They've given her a prescription for a narcotic and since the overdose, I must be the 'keeper of the meds' and hand one at a time to her.  Darn it!Time to write a 'gratitude list' and remind myself that it is a good thing I still can do what I can.My upper arm hurts from lugging her heavy purse around at the hospital...where the bicep tendon was torn is killing me today.  My back is screaming louder than usual from the weight and the chairs there.  My sleep was horrible, listening for any sounds from her being in pain and needing another dose...sigh...it just never ends with Cushing's.  So tough, having to be a caretaker when I need care, too!

Awe Pitmom,It sounds like you have your hands full right now.  I hope you get time to go outside and enjoy your beautiful plants and flowers.  Raining here for a few days.  Hopefully the rest of the snow will melt.Remember you aren't responsible for everybody.  Just yourself.  Don't spread yourself too thin.Take care of you...Hugs, Karen...

Pitmom,I hope things got better and that you were able to rest. I don't know much about your daughter's illness, so please forgive me if the following question sounds silly, but is it possible for you to get a part-time carer or caregiver for your daughter?  A carer could alleviate some of the stress of constantly taking care of your daughter.
Many healing thoughts to you all. Been dark myself but picking up. HT

Hi Forever Positive, don't feel silly for asking good questions.  First, my daughter is an adult (36).  She works.  Well, when she's able.  She'd have to see if she qualifies.I'm very angry with her right now.  This morning, I was doing more garden/property clean up since it wasn't raining.  She pops her head out the door and asks if I can take her to her job (within the hour) to get her paycheck?  The office would be closing at 11.  So, I stop what I'm doing (which relies on the weather) and take her.  We get in the car and she has her 18yo son with.  She asks if we can stop at Quik Chek first.  Fine, whatever.  Doesn't ask if I want anything, though.  Then, to her job.  Then, to the check casher.  Crutches, brace, the whole 9 yards!I made it worth my while and stopped at a store I like, briefly.  On the way home, she asks if I could take her later, to see her stepmother in the hospital, her step sister is coming up from Kentucky with the kids.  Not thrilled, I say 'Ask me later.'  Well, a good hour and a half before 'sister' is supposed to be there, she comes out of the house, no brace...and tells me she'll drive herself, since I didn't seem thrilled earlier.Now, I'm downright ticked off!  I dropped everything the other day to take her to the ER.  Dropped what I was doing this morning to take her for her check (which I never see any money from).  Now, I'm sure everyone there is saying she shouldn't be driving...and she'll blame it on me!  So, I've told her she can drive herself to her doctor on Monday and anywhere else she needs to go!  I'm DONE!

Pitmom,I can't imagine what your going through. It's such a tough situation as you want to be there for your love one, but you also need time for yourself.Is it possible for her son or another relative to help out and drive her to her appointments, etc? Hopefully, your daughter will seek out and qualify for part time caregiver.I hope you do something nice and relaxing this weekend.

I hope everyone is doing well. I spent most of today listening to podcasts on how to get out of debt. I have so much debt hanging over my head that it causes me anxiety. I'm very annoyed at myself for making poor financial decisions. Here I am 42 years old and don't even have a retirement fund or much savings. I feel I won't be able to progress as long as I have debt. I'm so motivated to be debt free. Listening to stories of how people were able to become debt free has really inspired me. I have to learn how to budget and not be an emotional spender.Anyway, my aunt invited me over for Passover. I don't know if I'm going to go. I love my aunt and her family, but they tend to be nosy and gossipy-like most family are I guess. Lol. Anyway, I hope everyone have a good weekend.Post Edited (ForeverPositive) : 4/19/2019 7:57:21 PM (GMT-6)

Beautiful, sunny and warm finally!!!  I hope to spend the day outside!!!I want to wish all of you a Happy Easter!!!  I hope you all have safe travels if you are going anywhere.Take care all.  Thank you FP!  You have a good weekend too!!!Hugs to all!!!Karen...

Happy Easter to everyone, whether you celebrate or not!I was raised Catholic and most of my family was quite devout, but I have slipped somewhat in that regard. Going to the Easter mass, seeing all those happy families with their kids only tends to be depressing, given how it's all pretty much alien to me.Still, in the past it was mildly amusing to see all the once- or twice-a-year churchgoers, all decked up in suits or dresses and make-up, often with their spiffed up or adoringly cute kids in tow, and having little clue as to what they were doing.

Our little choir sang for Easter at church - there are 6 of us, but our director is excellent - so that was fun.  I wore my pink wool blazer that I have worn almost every Easter for the last 15 years.  Fortunately, shoulder pads are making a comeback.The rest of my day has been very quiet.  It is just me and my mother in law here.  My mother in law is a nice lady but I have a deep seated resentment towards her because she has lived with us almost all of our married life  - 27 years in June.  This is my husband's 5th summer of running his hemp farm in southern Colorado which takes him away for 6 months of the year.  I really don't mind him being gone, but the responsibility for his mother is all mine now.  Anyway, I am just kvetching, she pretty much keeps to herself and does let the dog out when I am at work.  I hope everybody had a nice day and has a good week coming up.

Had a nice Easter Sunday.  Today I get to clean the mess.  But it was worth it.Suppose to be warm today, yay...  Then cold again, bummer.  I will appreciate the warm day today.I Hope you all have a good day.  I hope it is nice.Kathy, it is interesting your husband works on a hemp farm.  I think hemp can be good for a lot of things.  It is a good thing.I hope all is well with all of you.Hugs, Karen...

HI KathyHow interesting,  I was just justing at eco clothing made out of hemp and bamboo.  Pricey.  Plus nothing posted about how the fabric wears.  I would think it is most durable. Hope everyone had a good Easter or weekend if you do not celebrate. I was hit with an intense pain episode and had to cancel plans once again.  Oh well,  this is life right?Did get the back yard mowed today.  It was all I could do for the most part. Glad to do that. Changing the gardens in the front to easy maintenance and same in back where the grass dies if you breath on it.  Need to go to Home Depot this week or next.  One thing at a time. it will get done. Everyone a good week!PeaceTrina

HI KathyHow interesting,  I was just justing at eco clothing made out of hemp and bamboo.  Pricey.  Plus nothing posted about how the fabric wears.  I would think it is most durable. Hope everyone had a good Easter or weekend if you do not celebrate. I was hit with an intense pain episode and had to cancel plans once again.  Oh well,  this is life right?Did get the back yard mowed today.  It was all I could do for the most part. Glad to do that. Changing the gardens in the front to easy maintenance and same in back where the grass dies if you breath on it.  Need to go to Home Depot this week or next.  One thing at a time. it will get done. Everyone a good week!PeaceTrina

My husband essentially crushes up the hemp flowers and puts the powder into capsules.  It works the same as CBD oil for arthritis, etc.  My mother in law, who has chronic back pain, sprinkles it on her food or uses some made into a liniment and it works well for her.  The roots are used in Chinese medicine.  He has not found an outlet for the fibers at this point.I am not feeling so good today.
I hope you feel better Kathy.Thinking of you...Hugs, Karen...

Trina,  I gave up trying to grow grass.  I used to have a nice lawn...then I got a dog!  Between her paws and her pee, it was a losing battle.  I expanded the flower bed and have it planted with a few shrubs (backbone of the garden) and various Spring bulbs and summer rhizomes.  Crocus, daffodil, tulips, hyacinths for Spring.  Oriental lilies, Orienpet lilies, day lilies for summer.  I also have phlox, bee balm and perennial bachelor button mixed in.  All of this pretty much lives on whatever water the sky gives them!  It is densely planted...I only keep an eye out for any sign of disease caused by overcrowding...the weeds are kept at bay because the sun cannot reach them!  The 'backyard' has a colorful border surrounding the 'dust/mud bowl' where the dogs play.  More lilies, hibiscus (hardy type for NJ) oak leaf hydrangea (summer flowers, fall foliage color).  The end of the property gets the least attention, so I have drought tolerant plants there.  Ninebark, hibiscus, iris, coreopsis, a small barberry, yucca (bicolor) and catmint.  I'm sure I've missed several plant names, but you get the idea.  Really, the only things I water are what I plant in pots on the patio!

Beautiful day here today.  Sunny with a warm breeze.  Though I am wearing a sweater...Walked my dog and played with her outside. When I get angry and there is nothing I can do about it, it turns to depression and then I get self destructive.  Tonight that consists of eating a bag of chips and half a bowl of trail mix, which isn't great for my prediabetes.  I was set off when I stopped to buy my mother-in-law her adult diapers on the way home.  She never pays me back for these or groceries or anything else.  I have been supporting her for years and she has never said thank you.Before that, my day was OK.  It snowed and rained on and off all day, but there was no more accumulation.  My son is off visiting friends, so who knows when I'll see him next.  He is very different from his brother, who is more of a homebody.

Rain, rain and more rain.  The weeds are getting so far ahead of me!Turned my attention to the inside of the house.  Going from 'Farmhouse influence' to 'French Country influence'.  Most of the major pieces work either way.  I had 2 plastic dressers in the living room for out of season clothing and to provide a surface for my overwintering plants.  Yesterday, I went to Goodwill and found a buffet cabinet on nice legs (so I don't cover the heat duct) to replace them with.  Paid $24.99 for it!  Was going to paint it white and 'antique' it but now that I see it in the same room as my Mom's china cabinet (my t.v. cabinet) I think I'll leave it dark wood after all.Plenty of space for when I bring the plants back in.  For now, a tray with some amaryllis and a variety of metal urns/vases.  I folded one of my tablecloths as a 'runner' on top...greens and blues...I rather like it.  I also redid the display on the bookcase shelves with other thrifted items and some of my pottery collection.Fighting for my life...changing the things I can.

Kathy,I hope your prediabetes doesn't turn into full diabetes.  It happened to me.  I was on insulin for six months, but got to go off by watching what I eat.  Though I know trail mix is good...   I am sorry about your MIL and her actions, or not acting by paying you back.  Take it from your husband and it may force him to talk to her about it.  After all it is his mother...  Keep track of what you spend on her and tell him he owes you that back.  It really isn't cool of her to do that to you.  I hope your day is better today.  Starting to warm up a little here but not much.  Dark and dreary again.  But suppose to be nice and 70's on the weekend.Pitmom...  Great find on the buffet.  I hope it gives you years of pleasure.  I hope you guys have a good day...Hugs, Karen...

I have 2 'gothic' mirrors to hang and battery operated lanterns will hang opposite to be reflected back.Still fighting the negativity.  Had another talk with my daughter about expectations. Checking in.  Sunny today, but more rain again tomorrow.  Got two of the plants I wanted at the garden center yesterday...hyacinth bean vines (bought 2) and cuphea (bought 2).  The backs of the hyacinth beans are purple and it has lovely lilac shaded flowers late in the season and purple pods!  I potted them and hung the pots from the fence to fill in the trellises back there and give me privacy to boot.  The cuphea are a favorite of hummingbirds...annuals here...but I'm going to try bringing them in this winter.Rain = pain for me, so probably won't be on tomorrow. I had a nice weekend seeing the boys and the ducks and then heading to Utah.  While I was there I went for a short walk and mostly just putzed around.  Tonight I had dinner with my  old college roommate and her daughter.  So generally a good weekend and I am feeling better.

Finally got a sunny day today!  I want to reorganize the shed, get rid of some things and make room for a couple of things that have been in the house all winter.Garden weeding must also get done...but not all in one day...the weekend is supposed to also be nice.I went to the local Goodwill again yesterday.  Found a nice assortment of silver plate...bought a few pieces and redid the display on top of the t.v. cabinet, including some of my pottery and my grandmother's 'Praying Hands'.I've bought a vape system to help me get off cigarettes.  Half and half yesterday and most likely today...but this is the last pack of cigarettes I ever want to buy!  I got 'tobacco' vape and one flavored 'watermelon'.  Will stick with the tobacco one for now...then try switching to the watermelon for a bit to help me get off the vape!  I figure I'll switch to a watermelon candy or gum for that.  First things first, though.  My doctor wants me to stop smoking so much that he actually suggested I try vaping for a while.  The 'lesser of 2 evils' as it were.  The house already smells better and feels 'lighter'...if that makes sense.  I'm not telling a bunch of people...that has not worked well for me in the past.  Too much pressure and guilt if it didn't work out.  Obviously, my daughter and grandson know...and one friend who is also switched to vape.Now, to get my butt outside!

Can I whine just a little bit?  I started working this week at the job with the 75 mile commute - Monday, Tuesday and Thursday.  I am a mess, and it is only the first week!  Everything hurts, except maybe my left ankle - it feels pretty darn good!  (When I was having a lot of hip arthritis pain before surgery, I used to try to concentrate on an area of my body that didn't hurt).        There is a little light at the end of the tunnel.  I am going to get a keyboard tray that goes under the desk and the mouse will go there also.  I am planning on getting a new mouse that you can click with your thumb.  I have been wearing a wrist splint while I drive because I was getting carpal tunnel syndrome from the angle of my wrists on the steering wheel and the vibration.  I am going to try staying overnight on Monday to see if that's a viable long term plan.  But I am sooo tired.  I have been way overdoing the diet soda and hot tea to keep awake at work and on the drive.       OK, I'm done.  Thanks for listening.    Kathy

Sending positive thoughts to you all. Sleepless downunder!!Quiting the ciggies is a rough business...took me many yrs. But i did. 100 plus a day.  Fund a methos that suits...pick a start date....water...sipping helped...a technique i acquired by quit line in Australia.Yep barley lozenges or similar is good.  I seen a smoking cessation person...helped. I used me doc...did patches and slowly halved them. Reward yourself for achieving a goal set....like a number you will smoke etc and when a technique helped.Best do it when ya ready...however having a ceack at it and many cracks will actually be of benifit when you ya brain and body say yep.A small reduction each day or week is awesome as the cravings slowly reduce. My issue was not the nicotine per se...more the action of smoking...rolling them and using them as my go to as my coping skill.Why yoy smoke will help you in the process of reducing and or ceasing smoking. Hi karen.....Kind regards to you all. HT

I've been busy the last 2 days as the sun has actually been shining on NJ.  Weeding, dead heading, basic clean up still ongoing.  I also hung 2 gothic style mirrors in my bedroom, opposite the window.  I also had bought 2 battery operated lanterns and plant hooks, so they got put up, too!  They are reflected in the mirrors and I love the look!  The bulbs produce an amber light, rather than a white light.  Of course, all the overhead work left me in pain for a day...not just the shoulders, but the back, too!  I took it 'easy' yesterday...went to the salvage shop and found another piece for my pottery collection and just enjoyed the time with my friend.  Played with the doggies on and off.  Took a walk around the neighborhood and chatted a bit with whoever was also out.Had to use my T.E.N.S. unit for 2 hours last night...then had a restless leg night afterward...don't know which is worse...back pain or restless legs!  Shoulders are killing me...elbows are excruciating first thing in the morning.  Feel like the Tinman needing the oil can!On the bright side...I still have 3 cigarettes left in the pack I bought 3 days ago!!!  The vape is helping!  I know I'll have to then break that habit, too...but this is the most promising method just now...the patch causes skin irritation that resembles chemical burns, so that is not for me.  One step at a time!

It rained here off an on today - I guess practically the whole country is going to get this storm. I did not wash my car, so it is not my fault this time! He died 35 years ago and I still miss him.Jamie, I hope you are staying warm.  I keep forgetting you are heading into winter as we head into summer.

Hi Kathy,I am glad you had good memories about your Dad.  It sounds like things are going good for you.  I am happy for you.Yesterday was nice with my friend.  We were out for a few hours.  I had a little anxiety towards the end as I was getting tired, but all in all it was a fantastic day.  I am glad I got out.  It did me good.Beautiful Memorial Day.  Suppose to rain later though, as usual.  My cherry tree is blooming and it is so pretty.  It doesn't make cherries anymore, it use to.  But is always full of blossoms in the spring.Have a great day Kathy...Hugs, Karen...

Hi everybody.  Another 'rough patch'.  The roads in our trailer park are really messed up from the landlord putting in new water lines and new gas lines almost 10 years ago.  I've been trying to find a way to get them to fix this.  They also messed up our lease renewals again this year, so I'm trying to get that taken care of, too.  The problem is...my good friend here has been accusing me of having a 'special in' with the town council, because they have agreed to help sort things out here.  I've also heard that others have been saying I'm a trouble maker!Once this is all said and done, I'm going to try to just keep to myself and not take on these types of issues.  My world is shrinking as it is...isolation is not good for us...but I see no other way than to pull up the drawbridge and keep to my little castle.  The neighborhood has changed and there is no sense in making myself a target of nasty comments or worse!If I could move out of here, I would.  I'd hate leaving my garden, but I can grow one anywhere.  I'm very discouraged here, now.  Being active in my community helped me feel useful...still a member of society...it's all getting to be too much, though.On the bright side, I pruned some trees yesterday and the lilies are just about to bloom any day.  I've tossed quite a lot from the yard space this year and I'm liking how tidy things look.  Trying like crazy to keep the balance!

Don't even listen to what others are saying.  You know what is true.  It sounds like they are jealous.  You are a good person.  Remember that.Hang in there Pitmom.  Things will get better.Have a good day...Hugs, Karen...

Pitmom, I think your neighbors should be thanking you for getting things done for the community rather than criticizing you.  Some people!  I hope you don't isolate yourself - I have a tendency to do that too and it always makes me feel worse.  Maybe you could find a new "community", like volunteering at the animal shelter (they don't talk too much) or reading to preschoolers (they do, but they are pretty non-judgmental). It has been raining here, as well as everywhere else, it seems.  The clouds are clearing a bit and I can see snow on the mountain top, down to about the 9,000 foot level. (I am at 8,500 feet).  I hope it doesn't snow down here overnight .  My younger son is flying back to Seattle tonight  and my older son is up here for a day or two because he had a job interview in Denver today.  It's great to have them around and I am gong to be lonely when they are gone.  My dog is nice, but she is not a great conversationalist.

Hello! Although I am not new to HealingWell, I am new to this particular forum. I have recently (several months ago) gotten on Pristiq for depression. I now seem to feel exhausted all of the time as well as muddle-brained.  I was wondering if anyone else has had a similar experience with it.  It is doing a great job of controlling my symptoms of depression, anxiety, and anger, however, and I'd love to remain on it, but I cannot take this constant feeling of malaise and grogginess.  Coffee does not good.  Anyone have similar issues?  Thanks!

Hi SouthernChick,Welcome to the depression forum!  I take 150mg of Pristiq a day.  I been taking it since about 2010.  I have chronic fatigue from fibromyalgia so I take Adderall.  So I can't really tell if Pristiq makes me feel groggy or malaise.  I would talk to your doctor about it.  Maybe there is something that they can do to help.  Are you positive it is the Pristiq making you feel this way?  Sometimes it is something else and it is just at a coincidental time of the medication.Do you walk?  I find walking increases my energy and also helps me feel better emotionally..  Our weather is just now nice enough to walk.  So I am enjoying it.I hope you get some answers and that you find a way to feel better.  I am glad you are feeling better with the depression though.  I would stick with the Pristiq just for that reason..  Maybe add some Wellbutrin or something.Hugs, Karen...

Thanks, Karen.  I am hyper-sensitive to drugs and a little goes a long way with me.  Always have been.  I am only on 50mg but I swear it is taking a toll on me!  I can't fathom adding another to counteract the fogginess and malaise.  No, I am not certain it is the Pristiq, but that is one of the side effects and it did start at the time I began taking it. I took Wellbutrin for decades and then switched to another drug and was unable to get back on Wellbutrin due to head explosions and other problems.  I walk, but haven't gotten much in lately due to rain and back pain that I can't figure out. I'll talk to my doc, but was just wondering if anyone else on Pristiq had experienced the same mush feeling.
Have you ever tried Effexor?  It is similar to Pristiq.  Maybe it wouldn't give you that feeling.
No, I haven't. But I'll def ask my doctor about it.  Thanks!

I was on Pristiq for 9 years.  It controlled my depression well.  I know in the first month or two there can be some side effects that go away once your body gets used to the medication.  I don’t remember exactly what I felt the first month taking it but eventually it worked well without any major side effects.  I was switched to Cymbalta to see if it works better for my pain from Lyme disease but I have to say I liked Pristiq better.  Everyone’s chemistry is different though.  I didn’t do well on Wellbutrin at all.  The meds that worked the best for me were ones that had very little side effects from the start.

Hi Inspiredby3,Welcome to the depression forum.  I take Pristiq and it works well for me too.  Did the cymbaltra help with your pain at all?  Effexor is like Pristiq and sometimes for some people helps with pain.  It didn't really help me though for pain.  Neither has Pristiq.  But it helps a lot with depression.Hugs, Karen...

I took Effexor (venlafaxine) years ago, and while it helped my depression, it made me extremely tired, so much so that my kids noticed and started complaining that I was taking too many naps.  I switched to something else - I don't remember what now.

I've been taking this for one month for depression and anxiety. It has given me energy and helped me to focus, but my anxiety creeped back in yesterday, and I started to panic. From what I've read, it's more a medication for depression than anxiety.I can't deal with the anxiety anymore. It has taken over my life. I'm practicing mindfulness, but that only seems to work for a while until my thoughts take over.Grrrr...why did I have to be curse with these illnesses😡
I am glad your feeling betterMindfulness wonderful after a couple weeks.Peace Trina

I am too glad your depression is better but sorry the anxiety came back.  Can you take Xanax or something for that?  Mindfulness really does help.  But you have to keep doing it.  Maybe a little more each day until you do it naturally.  I do meditation too and it helps a lot with anxiety and sleeplessness.  Breathing exercises help too.Hang in there and let your doc know about the anxiety.  Hopefully they can give you something to combat the anxiety...Hugs, Karen...

author: Sad18yo
title: I’ve started feeling depressed and lonely

postContent.comment: I am 18, turning 19 in August. My parents made me drop out of school after junior high. I dealt with a bit of social anxiety but came close to making friends toward the end of 8th grade. Since I left school, I’ve never had any friends and rarely get to leave the house. I did very well in school, and I know I missed out in so many opportunities. A great high school here invited me to apply and I would have taken AP classes, been on the math team and all. Lately I’ve been feeling pretty depressed about it, not to mention pretty lonely. I should be graduating this year and as I look back, especially when I hear from other kids graduating this year about all the amazing things they’ve done and great times they’ve had, I realize that time went by so fast and I’ve done nothing. I’ve become really irritable, It’s really hard to get up in the mornings which is unusual for me, and I feel strange, sort of like I have no energy all day or desire to get out of bed in the morning, especially knowing I have nothing to look forward to but sitting at home and dealing with my parents who argue constantly and sort of use me as a pawn in the process. I could get my GED, but I have relatives that took that path and never got anywhere with it, and I’m not sure I’m ready for university. It’s tougher to make friends there, there is more stress, and I’m not sure It’s the best place for me right now. I have the opportunity, though, to go to a good high school here if I can test into senior year, which I’m confident I can. With a diploma, I could also apply to better universities and maybe get into a math/physics related program which I am interested in doing. I’ll be older than most of the other kids there, though (the closest is a senior who’ll turn 19 a couple months before the end of the year). Do you think I’ll be looked down on? Can I make friends and make up for what I missed out on? What would you do? Thanks.Post Edited (Sad18yo) : 5/25/2019 10:28:31 PM (GMT-6)

No mate...not looked down on at all. You do what is right for you...i went to uni as a mature age student and did stacks of prerequisites. I mean i dropped out of highschool at 15. Sounds like ya got some situational depression happening. Stay in school if ya can. At least get ya pass and take uni when ya ready.Soz ya down n stuff. Keep reaching out. Others will pop by with my info and support. Keep strong. Welcome to hw. HT

Yes, finish school if you can.  Why did your parents make you quit?  You sound smart, please go back and finish.  You may be a year older than others in uni, but that doesn't matter.  There are people who go at all ages.  It does sound like you have some situational depression starting and I think once you go back to school or get your ged, you will feel better about yourself.Hang in there, we are here for you...Hugs, Karen...PS welcome to the forum...

Absolutely get back to school. I quit at 16 - similarly a rough parent situation - and took it upon myself to get back at 18. Yeah, I was older than anyone else too but I had taken control of my own path and found nobody looking down on me. I ended up with my Grade 12, got work where could, kept learning as I went one place to another and have been in IT now for 35 years. You can do anything you put your mind to. Your parents have their own issues - they are not yours to take on - and if they are using you as a pawn, do not fear to tell them each to back the heck off.Keep coming back here - it HELPS!Brian

Hi.  My story is a bit different.  I stayed in school...longer than my classmates!  It was not 'fun' to return the year after I should have graduated with the others...but no one from the next graduating class so much as blinked an eye!  If you can enroll, please do!My daughter left school in her junior year...got her g.e.d. and has a good job.  She has taken some classes at the community college...hopes one day to get her degree.My grandson left school in 8th grade due to anxiety/panic issues.  Like you, he has missed out on much of the experiences of peers.  He turned 18 last month.  I'm not very worried for him, though.  Every adult that I talk with tells me how intelligent and articulate he is...how he is more mature than other teens they come in contact with...which will serve him much better than either type of diploma!  He will most likely go for a g.e.d. as it is the only real option for him.  If you have the opportunity to go back and finish high school and get the diploma, I think you should.  Being around others with the same interests and aptitudes will be good for you.  Just don't be surprised if their immaturity disturbs you...they've had a different focus than you've had.

Tripping out a bit. Tues, tomoz I have my NDIS planning meeting. This meeting, over an hr long will entail a plan for for funding on needs and supports I require funding for.You have to make it like a sales pitch, as it is all about the government wanting productivity returned, thus each area, or mobility, education, social support has to tie in towards short term medium and long term goals.Yes, many have been denied a lot of what they need. The person I am seeing is a local area coordinator, a contractor, this person will write the plan up and some bean counter in NDIS will either approve it, or just some of it.Trying to not read the horror stories....many. so sweating bullets. My mate is coming and will advocate for me. Think the turtle will need it, the agitation is manifesting. Am keeping calm.Don't overthink it Jamie, nor assume, Ah, good ol button's has just reminded me, just do it. Gp before I go missing one report. Walked up first thing, he in the morning.Send me positives. Cheers. HT.

Don't read the horrorstories-this will cause you more stress.Try not to stress ( I know easier said than done). When I'm stress, my mom always tells me ,' Que Sera Sera' ( whatever will be, will be) and that stress won't change my situation-it will only wreak havoc on my body and mind. Oddly enough, this helps me sometimes.Don't worry...you can do it.👍👍. Wishing you a massive amounts of good luck. Sending CYBER HUGS and postivity.😀😀Post Edited (ForeverPositive) : 3/31/2019 8:22:53 PM (GMT-6)
Wishing you all the best!You are very capable and I know you will succeed in convincing them to give you what you need!Let us know how you make out.

Not sure what NDIS is but I am assuming it is like our Social Security Disability here in the US.  I don't have that but I know people who do and it is a very long and arduous process and almost everyone gets denied the first time around and then they have to appeal.  I'm glad you have someone going along with you for moral support.   I like the Que Sera Sera idea from ForeverPositive.  Hopefully, something like this will decrease your stress levels.  (And now I will have that song going through my head all evening  - Was that Doris Day?)  Good Luck!!!!
Que Sera Sera, yes.....   I know you will get what you need Jamie...  I am sending positive vibes...And yes, do let us know how it goes.Hugs, Karen...

Best of luck! Hopefully you'll receive what you ask and need... Just as with the SSD process in the US, it's still mind-boggling to me that those who suffer must suffer more due to processes like this (while those who are already well off tend to become even better off).

I'm glad you have a mate to advocate for you. I was lucky I had my friend with me for my PIP assessment (that's a bit different, as it's a disability benefit rather than social care). It doesn't guarantee that I will get the award, but it certainly doesn't hurt my chances. The poor woman doesn't get a break though. First she helped her husband with his PIP assessment, then me, and now her daughter is due for an ESA reassessment! Just as she (the daughter) was starting to make plans for the future, this comes along and sets her back. Sorry, I went off track there. Anyway, definitely avoid the horror stories until it's over. And the best of luck!

Well.... my mate was great, I got agitated, stressed and so the neck and shoulders screamed. Still are. My mate advocated exceptionally.The bad news. Not under medical...only psych. So not additive technology, nor cleaning and gardens. My worker is putting a report in for an o.t, high level psycho-social and taxi funding.Was pissed the Gov didn't tell me no medical funding. The above is yet to be approved.PS I am on a disability pension  the NDIS, national disability insurance scheme is a life time funding process that is for people with significant disability. They took psych out for a few yrs but public outcry had it reinstated.The scheme is to provide assistance and services to promote wellness and productivity. The gov want us back as a pay as you earn member of society thus the intense scrutiny of claimants and the funding. You have to provide how the assistance services etc benifits you to wellness and productivity. Reviewed yearly.The worker I seen is caring, straight up and knows what the bean counters will and won't fund. So seven days for the report and a funding decision around a month. Seven months of stonewalling and he'll. They try hard to get you so despondent that you opt out. I have a rottweiler on my side, a clinical professor of psychiatry and formerly a director of our area mental health services. He had to lean hard on them he said. He a mental health warrior.Am tired. Love yas, and thx for kindness and support. HT.
I am glad things went okay Jamie.  I hope this will help you.  I don't understand a lot of it, but it sounds like it went well.  I hope you have a good night.Hugs, Karen...

Ok but not mate. No scooter. There is a program in my state for refurbished ones, need a referral and maybe the o.t can help. The funding might be crap for the next calendar year, we'll see. Cheers Karen and all HT at least I go at in, but a ball tearer of a process. Apt term, but can be edited. HT 😛😬
Sorry about the scooter.  I hope you can get a refurbished one.  Sorry it wasn't what you hoped.  Hang in there mate, things will get better.Hugs, Karen...

Jamie at least you and mate open a drip, drip drip from the faucet.If only these people live our lives for a week.  encluding 2 full weekends!Generosity would flow! right?Peace and strength for turtle with tenacity!

Am still waiting on the BS plan to be approved....I might get even less. And the plan put forward was a slap in the face anyway. Either way I don't give a expletive. Been in and out of Dark thoughts. It cold, I ache. Whatever......the Gov hates us...... HT
HTreturns,Try and hang in there. Things has a way of working themselves out.
How are Jamie?   Any news?   are you Meditating to relax your neck and shoulders?Prayers still going out!Peace and strengthTrina

It can be so frustrating to deal with any government agency.  I hope your situation gets taken care of quickly, so at least you know what's going to happen.  And I hope it turns out better than you expected!

As i have updated in the daily check in i did ok with the plan.I await an appt on the 21st of this month for a meeting with i hope a good service provider...they are well known in the mental health community...so this is promosing.Yes meditation group good...last session the bladder played up..enough said. Next week will be better.Thx for support guys.HT.
Yay Jamie,I hope you like the new doc...Have a good night mate!Hugs, Karen....
so glad to here the good news!Peace mate

Provider good. Signed up. Await appt for assessment and to advise them of the services i require. Place is relaxed. May pop in fri.Have stopped meditation group at thus time. Due to bladder reasons!!! Cough.⏩😞 doc and i are on it.Keep 💪. Thx for all positives. HT.
Excellent news!  I hope everything goes smoothly now.
All my best to you HTWeary

Cheers. Had assessment...know more next. Getting a worker. They have crap coffee....for participants and a ground espresso for staff....i said simething! We pay good coin for services and get saw dust! I mean my only vice these days is a nice cup of coffee. HT
As the title says it took me weeks and instead of zoloft I'm trying John's Wort now. Depressed again but oh well it keeps it at bay and I know it could be a lot worse.

Hi Andrina, I'm glad you were able to taper off the Zoloft, hopefully with minimal side effects.  I remember years ago, before anyone really knew about antidepressant withdrawal, I stopped Effexor cold turkey.  Of course, I had all kinds of weird symptoms and wound up getting a brain MRI which showed some sort of vein malformation which meant I had to see a neurologist and get another MRI (all fine, thank goodness)Are you getting any exercise to boost your natural antidepressants?  I find it is really helpful.

That's good to hear... glad it worked, or at least did something. I was prescribed Zoloft, but it only made things worse over several weeks, and I couldn't take it anymore. I'm wondering whether people suffer something similar and achieve a breakthrough if only they last it out?

I know for me I needed to be on zoloft for a few weeks for it to fully kick in.Not doing exercise as I'm in between surgeries. Maybe once recovered I can finally think about it. The John's Wort is actually really helping and helping fast. I'll stick with it. Before I was on birth control and immunosuppressive meds which would have interacted with the John's wort but after my first surgery I weaned myself off of all medications and I haven't taken birth control in years (I have a copper iud <3). I realized I can finally give it a go. I'm so glad I did!
Good stuff. St johns wort does help many peeps. HT

HI Miranda,Just wondering how you been.  Haven't seen you post here in awhile and hoping everything is okay.  When you get a chance, post and let us know how you are doing.  I hope you are doing good.Hugs, Karen...
Howdyplanning a  vacation or extended stay in Ireland no doubt!heeheeheehugsPeaceTrina

Hi folks. Not doing great I'm afraid. I'm nowhere near going to Ireland; in fact I still haven't got all the necessary documentation - my Irish grandfather's birth certificate was just the start. I need to get on with it, but summoning the motivation to do anything is nearly impossible. I'm just tired. Tired of the uveitis, tired of the Crohn's, tired of medical appointments which never go anywhere, and tired of fear. Lost hope of having a better life or of meeting anyone new. I can't talk to people in this state, so I don't. I think the uveitis was the final straw which broke me to be honest. I now have panic attacks about going blind - a worry I did not have until a year or two ago. If I could see a decent eye doctor who could either convince me I won't go blind or get me onto some treatment other than steroid eye drops (which in their turn can cause sight-threatening complications), then maybe, just maybe, I would feel like somebody was on my side for a change. instead of me battling indifference everywhere I go. I even tried a private consultation at Moorfields and didn't like the doctor I saw.  So yeah, not much point posting while I'm in this state really. I'm just hanging on for my cataract operation on the 14th June. That scares me as well though, because if my vision somehow ends up worse I know I won't be able to cope with it.Edit: Well, I had a shower and feel a tad better now :/ I am off to bed. Got to get up early tomorrow 'cos a repairmen is coming round to repair the heap of junk that is my kitchen cupboard - the door came away from the wall when I opened it. And then I've another medical appointment, oh joy. What I would give to go back 20 years in time and never see another hospital waiting room. I ought to be grateful because I don't pay for my treatment and intellectually I am, but emotionally I am just so tired of it. Anyway, I'm tired. Maybe I will feel a bit better tomorrow if I can grab enough sleep. Goodnight folks, I hope you are keeping well.Post Edited (NiceCupOfTea) : 5/15/2019 5:31:05 PM (GMT-6)

Hi Miranda,Try to enjoy seeing things while you are able to, just in case things get worse.  Enjoy every little thing, birds, animals, the ducks.  We all never know what could happen tomorrow so it is best to enjoy today.  I hope your surgery goes well for the cataracts.  I am going to have to have that done in the future myself.  I have them but they are small right now.  When my blood sugar was high my eyes went whacko.  Even my glasses didn't work.  It took three months to get back to normal.  So I know it can be scary.  Sometimes it helps to post even if you don't feel well..  Sometimes it makes you feel better.Hang in there Miranda.Hugs, Karen...

I'm sorry you have all this uncertainty in your life right now.  It might be kind of nutso over here on this side of the pond, but we don't have to deal with the Brexit mess.  But I think you'll feel a lot better when your cataract surgery is behind you.  My grandmother had hers done 50 years ago and she did fine, and you know they've gotten a lot better at it in that amount of time!

Thanks Karen.There is no way I can live with being blind, especially on my own and with little or no support. That gets me onto a subject I can't talk about openly on here, but hopefully it will never come to that. I will do my utmost best to preserve my sight. I saw the ophthalmologist today and she was actually a lot more helpful than the private doc I saw for £340 - I still feel mugged tbh. But anyway, she did manage to allay a few of my worries about the cataract operation. Apparently steroid-induced cataracts are a lot easier and safer to remove than uveitis-induced ones (my ones will be steroid-induced, because I haven't had the uveitis long enough to get cataracts from it). So at least that's one bit of good news. Everything else is about the same. One drop at night time seems to be keeping the inflammation under control for now. I have known it flare up even with one drop a day, so I'm not going to risk stopping the drops. Certainly not before the op, where it's important for the eye to be inflammation-free. The ophthalmologist did say that the operation would cause the uveitis to flare up, which didn't surprise me - the body doesn't like being cut into, no matter which part it is. But I guess steroid drops will deal with that... @Buena76 - Yes, cataract operations have improved enormously. There's far fewer complications from them than there used to be. As for Brexit, I don't think my brain can deal with it anymore. It is a black hole of deceit and corruption that draws all who go near it into its unescapable gravitational pull. It is an ideological cult whose members worship at the altar of the One True Brexit (Let's Go WTO). It is... I can't go on. Too depressing. I can't even predict anymore how it will all end, apart from badly.

You write so well Miranda, have you ever thought about writing a book or short stories?  Just curious.  I hope that the surgery goes well for you.  Did you say when it was?  I have no brain as I just got up.  I know how you feel about being mugged.  Every thing is so expensive here right now.  It costs an arm and leg for everything you need.  I hope things get better and you feel better soon.  I think after the operation you will feel much better as that will be one less thing to worry about.  Keep posting if you feel up to it because it does help to get your feelings out.  Know we all care about you.Take care Miranda...Hugs, Karen...

Thanks Karen! Very kind of you to say so. I have actually. I just have one teensy problem: I can't think up plots to save my life <_<. The operation is on the 14th June. I don't have a date for the second eye yet, but it should be done quite quickly after the first eye - about two weeks I was told. I do feel a bit better today. All this business with my eyes has sent me tailspinning into another depression. I wouldn't say I'm out of it by a long way, but it's nice to have a respite and feel, if only partially, like my 'old' self again. By the way, I haven't forgotten about getting a dog but I'm going to get the cataract surgeries done first. Once they're out of the way, I should feel a lot better. Hopefully.Hugs back >.>

I think you will feel better Miranda when it is all over.  I hope it goes well, and I hope it is easy.  I will have to have it done in the future.  Mine are small.  Well they only said one eye I think.  I could be wrong.  I don't look forward to it at all.  But it is what it is I guess.  Yes, I think you would be very good at writing a book.  You write well.  I was told once I should because of my disfunction in my family.  Autobiography or something.  Maybe some day it will all fall into place for me to write.  But for now, I am not interested.  I remember my grandmother was always trying to write.  She did a short story and it was published in Reader's Digest.  It was called Teacher For A Day.  I think it was about her sister as she was a teacher.  I am glad you feel somewhat better.  I hope it continues.  I been a little down over something I don't think I can control.  Insurance company messing with my antidepressants.  They wont pay for what I need.  I got the worst insurance company and not by choice.  Oh well, another "it is what it is".  So I will make due somehow.I hope you have a good rest of the day.  Take care,Hugs, Karen...

Hi Karen. This will be a short reply, because once again I've stayed up too late playing Xenoblade Chronicles on my 3DS <_<. I had to give up playing Geometry Dash because it was starting to really hurt my hand and forearm and it was getting worse, not better. Both my arms are sore, but it's worse in the right arm and radiating down into my hand, making it a bit numb and tingly. Using the laptop isn't helping either - I tried an ergonomic mouse but it didn't make much difference unfortunately. This has gone on for several weeks already. I wasn't going to go to the doctor about it, but I think I will soon if it gets no better... I honestly don't think there's a bit of me left which isn't falling apart. Toes maybe. I think my toes are still okay. I also finished the 5th and final book of the Hitch Hikers Guide To The Galaxy series, so I've been managing to fit in some reading too. To be honest, I can't understand half the plots I read/watch nowadays, let alone think them up :-( I was fine until the very end, but there's something I still don't get about it and it's bothering me. It's bloody annoying to get through 5 books and then not quite understand the ending. My brother (the one who died...) was an aspiring writer too. I still intend  to read a book he wrote called Boris Goes To The Supermarket. It was on the Amazon bookstore - I downloaded it for my mum onto her kindle. Unfortunately I think it's gone from Amazon now, although if has I can always copy my mum's version over to my kindle. That's not the problem. The problem, for both of us, is reading it. We think it's going to be pretty depressing... :/ I am sorry about your meds. Would your doctor get in touch with the insurance company and say you need these particular meds? Are they giving you a cheaper alternative or stopping your meds completely? I ended up writing a long post after all. Oh well <_<. I am going to be off to bed after this though. Really do need to start going to bed earlier...Goodnight Karen :p

Hi Miranda (is it OK if I call you that?),I'm glad your toes are feeling OK.   My left ankle is doing pretty good.  The rest of me is falling apart, too.  Or at least it feels like it.  There is a big storm coming through, maybe that's what it is .  Hi Karen,I hate it when the insurance company messes with your meds.  I have taken a zillion different ones that haven't worked well and they still want me to go back to one of the old ones or get a prior authorization for the new one.... again!  I seriously doubt the people who run those pharmacy companies have ever had to deal with depression, or anything else serious .  Well, I could go on all day about that, so I won't. Hope both of you had a better day todayKathy

Hi Kathy and Miranda,The insurance company made me cut back on my medication and I think I will be okay.  I take 100mg now instead of 150.  They have always said 150 is no better than 100 with this particular med (Pristiq).  I feel alright but the initial switch was a little scary.  I thought it was going to effect me more than it did.  I am glad it didn't.  I think I will be okay.  Doc said I can maybe add something or switch to something else.  So far so good.  It was hard at first but I think a lot of it was fear on my part.I hope you both are having a good day today.  Thunderstorms suppose to be here.  I don't think it will ever warm up here.  We had a long dreary winter and a dreary spring so far.Hugs, Karen...
Good news Maranda!  Glad your worry is down a couple pegs.  I am sure you will be ok. I believe you found a good doc to deal with.Peace
Many healing thoughts to you all. HT

@Buena/Kathy  - Yes, that's fine. One good thing about here is that when you start a med, you can usually stay on it permanently - there's no insurance company to mess around with dosages, etc. However, not all meds are equally available. Medications are only licensed for particular conditions and getting a medication prescribed off-label seems to be virtually impossible, e.g. Wellbutrin for depression, biologics for my type of uveitis. Plus getting a GP to prescribe sleeping pills or tranquilisers is harder than getting blood out of a stone. Anyway, I spent the day at my mum's friend's house yesterday. Her ISP had sent her a letter saying that her husband's email may have been used to send spam, thus they were blocking all her email accounts. Her husband sadly died 3 years ago of cancer. What an absolute nightmare it was trying to sort it out. Endless phone calls, endless waiting in queues with some of the worst pop music I've ever heard in my life, endless being passed from pillar to post. And after 2 hours of this wretched crap, the problem wasn't even sorted. Apparently the IT team will call back within 5 working days to sort out a new password and will delete the husband's email accounts in the meantime. I give it 50/50 it will happen. The second problem was luckily a million times easier to solve. Someone had enabled Audio Description on her TV by accident and the voiceover had been driving her mad for the last 1-2 weeks (she was a bit vague as to when it started). Neither she nor her lodger could work out how to get rid of it. Once I knew what it was, it was easy to find and switch off in the TV settings. Then I found the TV remote shortcut and showed it to her, in case it happened again and she needed to know how to switch it off. She thinks I'm a technological genius, when I really am not. I just know how to find my way around menus and decipher them :-/ @Karen - Very glad to hear that the drop of dosage doesn't appear to have done any harm. It's always a bit of a risk tapering or stopping antidepressants, so I'm glad it didn't affect you adversely. @Trina  - Thanks. I am still worried, but just trying not to think about it for now I guess. I can worry about Brexit instead. It's the EU elections tomorrow , so I'm going to vote Green. Tactically, voting Lib Dem would probably make more sense, but it turns out I can't forgive the Lib Dems for their collusion with the Tories in government after all. I am so angry about what has been done to our country. The report by the UN special rapporteur, Philip Alston, into poverty and hunger is absolutely brutal. And what makes it worse is that the government is still gaslighting the entire country and denying everything the UN report says. When you only have to open your eyes, read a few things and talk to a few people to see the UN report is true and the government is lying. Meanwhile, the PM is on the brink of being forced out. The only way she is leaving is being dragged out of Number 10 with a bottle of gin, so the Tories are voting to change the leadership rules so that she can be subjected to another vote of no confidence and forced out that way. She was subjected to one last December, won it, and was supposedly immune to another challenge for 12 months. This country has turned into a basketcase. Today, a man was caught on video at a Brexit rally shouting "***ing traitor" over and over again at a remain campaigner (who was standing with a placard and wasn't harassing anybody). He poked the remainer with a Union Jack flag on a pole and then went and screamed "losers!" at a bunch of other people offscreen. Later on, he was identified as being the senior mental health lecturer at King's College University. That broke me a little. Sometimes there are no words to express the deep down awfulness.  Anyway, sorry for going on. I will shut up now, and go to bed >.> @HT - Thanks, and the same back to you.

Best of luck to you with the surgery on the 14thChronic illness is a drag....I remember how hopeless I felt when my RA was at it's worst.Thank God I was able to get it very manageable with medicationAll My Best-Weary
Thank you weary! I do agree, chronic illness is a complete drag. Having pain every day, even low level pain, is debilitating. Anyway I am glad you were able to get your RA under control.

I would like to inform everybody about  my situation and hopefully it will help someone  who is suffering from chonic depression.Six years ago I was diagnosed with chonic depression and started on an anti-d..Some worked for a short time and some did nothing  for me so I went through 18 different anti depressant meds in six years.I was treated by my G.P. (glorified plumber ) and by two psychiatrists.and every time they would change my meds or add on another med .Never did they  question their  diagnostic.All this time I  searched and searched mental illness blogues,books,journals,etc.Eventually, I went to the Mayo clinic site , did a couple of tests and found out that I was bipolar 11 . The meds that all these good MD s  were giving me were making me worse.I then found a private clinic and after passing some tests and many questions , they confirmed that I was bipolar 11.
