The doctor changed my medication.In just one week after going on Lamictal (mood stabilizer ) I started to feel better (the rest is history) We all think that Doctors are gods and can do no wrong but  three doctors made the same mistake and I suffered for  6 years .The doctor who confirmed that I was bipolar and started my on a mood stabilizer told me that this happens quite often because we go to see our doctor when we feel depressed so, they medicate you for depression.Bipolar people have highs  and lows.We do not go to see a  doc.when we our in a high and feel good.I just finished reading an article in the AARP journal about a man who went though the same thing as I did, but for FOURTY THREE years.I always thought  that bipolar people  ,( when they are in the high (mania ) )would go out and spend money  like fools,gamble,have sex with just about anyone,etc..That is not  always the case and there different types of bipolar.If your situation is like mine ,  maybe you are really suffering from depression and difficult to medicate or  maybe ,you have the wrong diagnostic and suffering from another mental illness.Some doctors are very good but  all   humans make mistakes ..  Take care.Post Edited By Moderator (BnotAfraid) : 5/2/2019 8:04:52 AM (GMT-6)

Hi FT,Thank you for sharing your experience.  It makes perfect sense that you would only talk to the doc during the depressive part of bipolar.  I use to wonder if I were a little manic.  But it only happens when I get mad.  I don't have manic episodes at any other time that I am aware of.But there are many people that go misdiagnosed.  Like you say, doctors are only human and they do make mistakes.I hope you are having a good day and thanks again for sharing.Hugs, Karen...

PT Thank you for your post.You are not alone in your struggle.  It is true GP's have limited knowledge on bipolar.  However,  bipolar is hard to diagnosis and there are different types of bipolar where the symptoms are completely different.So unless you are lucky enough to have a Psych who specializes in BP, chances are a misdiagnosis will happen.It is how it is, for now.Self compassion to help being your own advocate is all I can  suggest.Peace and strengthTrina

Yeah, my heart goes out. If I hadn't had the same experiences you've had, I'd feel even worse.But I have had the same experiences. I'd had six years plus getting misdiagnosed as a depressive when I was really manic-depressive. What would happen would be the anti-depressant would send me into mania and then panic attacks. Then I guess they would treat the panic attacks, which were caused by the medicine they gave me to begin with. Or, they would ignore the panic attacks and say, "Well, what was going on when you had the panic attack?" as if it was my fault, or the environment did it. If they miss-diagnose, they miss-medicate. If they miss-medicate, you're not really being treated, you're being miss-treated. Which is why the diagnosis is so important.With computers and people being able to go to the net looking up such topics in the search engine as "depression" or "manic-depression" (now called bipolar) or "anxiety" or "post traumatic stress disorder" (PTSD) or any such physical or mental ailment, doctors aren't the only ones who can try to determine what condition a person has.And doctors have from 5 to 20 minutes or so to figure it out. Patients have all the time they want, from an hour to weeks if they want looking on a computer, printing out items of interest. They can even print out the symptoms of bipolar or depression or anxiety or whatever, and on the printout check off the symptoms they have to see if they quality for that illness.They can even take the printed out sheet to their doctor and show him or her what they and the doctor think. If the doctor doesn't agree, they can either discuss it or the patient can even get another doctor if the patient thinks the doctor is n ot the right one for them.   Doctors being the only ones who decide such matters went out with the era of men-only doctors, which was decided on by who, men, right, that makes sense, to male doctors. But men and I suppose women psychiatrists are still making the same mistake of diagnosing patients who come in as depressive as depressive, without asking one question, "Do you ever have a racing mind. Do you have trouble sleeping?" to see if they are manic-depressed. As far as computers, I was at the public library yesterday, and they have plenty of free computers. All you need is a free library card. You can look up various mental conditions on the search engine. The assistants will show you how to do that. You can then print out any pages you want, which the assistants can show you how to do.Going through 18 different anti-dep pills when your problem was actually bipolar is very said. In addition to my anti-dep., mirtazapine, I also take Lithium as a mood stabilizer, which keeps my anti-dep from throwing me into mania or and/or panic attacks.    Good that you "went to the Mayo clinic site , did a couple of tests and found out that I was bipolar 11 ." You solved that problem on your own.

We know our minds best, yes this sadly happens...soz mate. Been down this road. The other factor to keeo in mind is:A dx can change or another Can present itself on top of a preexisting dx.Bi polar disorders can be tricky to dx. Esp if the doc sees no mania or mixed mood. Thx for sharing.Keep strong...

Hi HTTIM Tam. long time no see. how are you!Good stuff.  PT.  Try to give your self some compassion think of what you would tell a friend in the same situation.   This is the beginning of you becoming your own self advocate.  Tough job,  yes sadly I know.  IN the end.  You will be proud and empowered, I promise you that. Small steps, listen to your body,  research major hospitals around the world, learn.   Talk to 3 nurtrisinist with 3 different base attitudes/thinking. Step out of the box of your pain,  think of the world around you, what do you encounter,  what enters, touches, you're body?  what do you inhale, what do you or don't you eat.   open your mind wider so your thinking can expand, the pain can ease,  take notes on anything. and everything, at some point you get an aha moment ,  something will click the n your pain is down and your are happier. I wish your peace and strengthTrin a
Thank you all,for your input !!!!

author: ktp812
title: Extreme Chronic Fatigue as the major symptom

postContent.comment: I am on day 7 of Prozac 10mg with no side effects which is promising. I will up to 20mg in another week. My main symptom which I have been dealing with for more than 8 years is chronic tiredness. I wake up tired...unrefreshed...even though I most of the time sleep pretty good. I have dreams and when I wake I usually fall back to sleep. I do have other depression symptoms such as crying spells..get extremely fatigued when I have to concentrate on something...sometimes so unmotivated I can’t do anything. But the fatigue is what is debilitating. When I wake up tired then the day doesn’t have much hope.I have read that extreme fatigue is a symptom of depression but it is my major symptom. I have to rest (not sleep) every afternoon. I usually can’t do night time activities. I tire out easily mentally.The fatigue does not feel like a “normal” tiredness. It just feels bad and I can’t go on with the day like a normal person would be able too with tiredness. I guess I am wondering if anyone else has this has their major symptom and if the anti-depressants helped. I have taken Wellbutrin in the past but it didn’t give me any energy at all. I have had sleep studies done...no apnea or restless legs. But still I wake exhausted. I don’t really qualify for CFS as I only have two symptoms on the list. Can anyone here relate?

I have chronic fatigue too.  I think mine is from fibromyalgia.  I don't have a lot of symptoms of CFS either, but I have the fatigue.  Antidepressants can help but don't always.  I take Adderall and it helps.  I am on generic and it doesn't help as much as brand name, but it does help.  I take Pristiq and it doesn't make me as tired as some antidepressants.  I hope you find something to help.  When I first got the fibromyalgia, I slept for two years.  So I missed out on two years of my life.  It wasn't fun.  I hope yours doesn't get that bad.Hugs, Karen...

@Karen- I don’t have fibromyalgia...I do have neuropathy in my left calf but it’s not bad enough to take medication for it. The only real symptoms I have is the chronic debilitating fatigue and poor sleep. I don’t think the poor sleep has a huge impact on the daily fatigue since it isn’t a need for more sleep...I would never be able to sleep during the day. I am sure the Prozac is adding some to the tiredness right now but it would still be crippling even if I wasn’t on anything. It really isn’t a need for energy. It’s more of being mentally tired and exhausted if that makes sense. I can’t wait for my appointment next month. I am busy typing up my lists of symptoms...medications and tests I have had in the past 13 years. It’s easier just to hand them to her because it’s massive and I would never remember everything. The tiredness is well exhausting to deal with..I might very well have CFS or just idiopathic fatigue and it will never be figured out.

It's a good idea to take tests and write things down so that the doctor can look at them.  I hope that your appointment goes well and that you get some answers.  I have found that walking helps both mentally.  And it doesn't have to be a long walk.  If I can get out there for about ten minutes of walking it helps me.  I feel less exhausted and better mentally, in other words I can think.Let us know how everything goes for you.  All I ever want to do is sleep.  But I push through it the best that I can and that is with the aid of medication.  I hope it gets better for you.  Hugs, Karen...

@Karen- I will keep posting on my journey with Prozac. It’s only been a week but at least the only side effect I have is more fatigue. All I want to do is lay down as I feel so tired. I just went out for a 15 minute walk in between thunderstorms. I love nature and the outdoors but sometimes I just can’t manage even a short walk. I still have to wonder if this is CFS as a doctor diagnosed me with it but I think he just didn’t know what was wrong as fatigue being my primary symptom...The doctor appointment is on June 18 so I definitely will post on that. I have been to so many different doctors I am not sure this one will be any different. But...I have to go and see if she comes up with something.

I know how you feel, once I got a diagnosis, it was somewhat easier.  At least I knew what I was dealing with.  The problem is not a lot of doctors always believe in fibromyalgia.  More now than use to though.  But it was like a mystery illness and some doctors don't know how to treat it.  But I been living with it now for about 17 years.  And it isn't as bad as it was unless I just got use to it.I have pain and fatigue.  I handle the pain much better than the fatigue mentally.  I hope that the Prozac works well for you.  It can take six to eight weeks for the medication to reach full potential.  But you can feel better in the meantime.  At least you say you don't have much side effects, that is a good thing.  Keep me posted...Have a good evening...Hugs, Karen...

Karen- It’s true that in the past many doctors didn’t believe in Fibromyalgia or CFS . I have a friend who is on disability because of Fibromyalgia . It took years for her to be diagnosed and then the long process of filing. She had a job she loved and made good money which is what is so frustrating about the validity of these illnesses. No one would chose to be disabled over a great job and normal life. At least it is more recognized now. No matter what chronic symptoms we are dealing with it’s difficult. I hope the Prozac is the culprit in my increased tiredness. I am just a limp rag almost. I had to lay down for a couple hours but it never makes a difference...just necessary. I will at least stay on the Prozac until I see the doctor. That will make it about 7-8 weeks I would have been taking it. I should know by then if it’s helping and if not maybe she has another suggestion. I just really can’t take anything that will cause ungodly fatigue as I have enough of that already.Take careKim

Hi Kim,I tried to get social security disability but was denied.  The administrative law judge said I could work in a ticket booth somewhere.  Wow, really?  I appealed it but still was denied.  So I am glad your friend got it.  It is sad when you don't feel well enough to work.  I did end up working for awhile at a convenience store/gas station and I loved it but when it got real cold I couldn't get myself to go out in the weather.  So I ended up taking a leave of absence but I didn't go back.  I did enjoy it though while I could do it and felt good for being able to.  I imagine the Prozac could be the culprit, but that could go away in seven to ten days.  That is what they say anyway.  So there is hope.  I know how you feel about the fatigue, It does make life hard.  I remember having to  hang on to furniture just to get around the house.  It was like I was so weak.  I am glad those days are over, at least I hope that they are.  And I hope that the Prozac helps you.  I know it is hard but hang in there.  You will get better and I hope that it is soon.Hugs, Karen...

Hi Karen- I am thinking now about discontinuing the Prozac as yesterday I was so tired I couldn’t function. I am going to take it later in the day like during lunch and see if the tiredness is as bad.I know it’s said that it does go away but when the fatigue is bad to begin with...adding more is really horrible. I didn’t have this the first days so not sure why it’s happened for now. If that doesn’t work then I will discontinue for now and wait to talk with the doctor. Maybe I won’t need anything . I know Prozac is one of the ones that cause less fatigue so I don’t know. I still take 150mg Wellbutrin so I will keep on that. Thanks for all your encouragement...I will keep you posted. It’s a beautiful sunny day here so we are going to drive to the lake and check on the Eagle family. The eaglets are close to flying and would love to witness that! Take careKim

Maybe taking it before bed might help.  Instead of in the morning.  I am sorry it is making you more fatigued.  There is also Lexapro???  Maybe that wouldn't make you fatigued.  I am sure your doc will have some ideas.Now once I went off SSRI's and switched to SNRI's I was less fatigued.  The SNRI's I know of are Effexor and Pristiq.  They have antianxiety agents in them.  I hope that this helps some.That would be nice if you only needed the Wellbutrin.  Can you talk to the doc before your appointment?  I would call and ask what you should do.  I hope you are able to enjoy the day.  Sunny here for a change and warmer.  I will walk the dog today for sure.  Yesterday was windy and cold so I didn't go.Take care Kim.  Thanks for writing back.Hugs, Karen...

Hi Karen- I cant take Effexor as it was on my genetic “no” list. Pristique I think was okay to try. I have never seen the psychiatrist so I don’t think she would recommend anything. I was given Prozac from my PCP who recommended I see the other doctor. I am going to see how I feel today without the Prozac this morning. I mean I am always tired anyway but hopefully I will be able to get some stuff done. Then after lunch I will decide what to do. I am back taking Klonopin to sleep...a quarter milligram is all I need. I had been off it for a year but now am having trouble falling asleep again. I don’t like to but I do what I must in order to sleep. I will keep you posted. Kim

I take Xanax on occasion or some old ambien that I have.  But I don't know if this would work for you, I meditate at night to fall asleep and it works real well.  Look into it.  Then you get a natural sleep.  I am glad you have the klonopin for sleep.  We heal and rest when we sleep and the body needs that.I been seeing a psychiatrist for awhile.  I see a psychologist too.  The psychologist is my therapist.  I think my psychiatrist is going to retire from the practice, either that or just work with veterans.  But my psychologist will be able to write my prescriptions.  So that is good, but I foresee her retiring soon too.  Then I will have to find another doctor to write my prescriptions.  That isn't going to be fun.I hope you have a great day with some energy or less fatigue.  I hope you get a lot done, I have yet to see that day.  I get things done but not a lot.Hugs, Karen...

Hi Kim,Depression itself can cause a fatigue that blows your mind.  some days all I can do is take care of my to dogs and that is about it!  some times I even forget to feed them when I am bad.  I can understand why they keep asking for something Then I realize!!!. LOLI have found though the years,  that battling through the tiredness getting out side for a 10 min walk or even sitting on your front steps for  10min can make all the difference. I found myself a hobby, I make lap blankets for local Alz. units and that keeps my hands busy.  Busy hands. healthy minds. lSupport groups help too. I mediatate,   the is a great app free Insight time.  For your phone.  If you don't like it you can uninstall it.I know how are this is,  I know how frustrating it is when you can not find the med the will work.   Kim you are not alone.  And you are not lost.  You will fine an anwser.  in the meantime.  slow down be your own advocate and give yourself some TLC.    INSIGHT TIMER..... so many things to help you....PeaceTrina

Hi Trina- The problem is I have been struggling with fatigue since 2004. Back then before I knew I had Lyme it was more of an exhausting feeling. The fatigue I have had for the past ten years is different. Maybe it is from depression but back in 2010 when it started I know I wasn’t depressed.I had successfully treated Lyme...working part time..traveling ...living my life.Then gradually the fatigue crept in and became more and more debilitating. Over the years I also became intolerant to noise...light...crowds...malls...restaurants. I would get very overstimulated. I can’t have night activities because I am too tired. Shopping is exhausting....I have trouble on the computer and watching television...the sound and movement is stimulating. Insomnia since 2004.I am under the impression that whatever causes all this has given me depression because it’s been so long. I know I failed the depression questionnaire but I am very frustrated that I can’t do things...not that I don’t even care I can’t. I could go on and on.... I have read depression causes wicked fatigue but have never read where it causes all my other major issues so I just don’t know if antidepressants would even help. I guess that’s up to the doctor to decide. I am possibly depressed but also could have CFS? I have some meditation apps on my phone and will check yours out too. I also do heart math several times a day. I try to walk daily even if I feel tired...I go out with a friend if I am able. I do whatever I am able.Thanks for writing...I appreciate it.Kim
Have you had your thyroid levels checked?  How about your cortisol level?  These 2 hormones can wreak havoc on the body.

@pitmom- I have my thyroid checked ever six months because I am hypothyroid and on medication. I had my cortisol levels checked five months ago and they were perfect. I also recently had the ACTH STIM test and it was normal as well. My adrenals are in good working order. I think everything you can think of I have been tested for! I can tell you everything is normal except my cholesterol.

Sometimes we don't even realize how poorly we are sleeping!   When my Lupus was more active I was sleeping 10-12 hours at night and so tired I couldn't hardly move during the day.. naps, etc.  Slept like the dead.I was totally mystified when my rheumatologist suggested a sleep aid! I thought he'd gone off his rocker, or confused me with another patient.  I thought I was sleeping more than enough, and the sleep study really didn't find any problems. What could he possibly be thinking???!So I took the Trazodone he recommended.  And started sleeping only 10 hours and waking up refreshed!  Still had a bit of a tendency to need a nap in the late afternoon -- but after I stopped with the soft drinks and the processed carb snacks even the need to nap disappeared.So, you might start by adjusting your diet and trying some over-the-counter sleep aids, like Melatonin.  Can't hurt, right?Best wishes,

@Lynnwood- I took Lunesta for 6 years. Then quarter Klonopin for 6 years. I quit both last year and had a terrible time falling and staying asleep. I just recently started taking quarter Klonopin and Melatonin. I sleep fine but not refreshed and I am constantly tired even if I don’t do anything the fatigue is present. I have a very long list of things I have tried for sleep including pharmaceutical and herbal. I couldn’t tolerate Trazadone at all. It just made me unbearably drowsy but I couldn’t fall asleep. Then the hangover was awful. The only things that helped me sleep were Lunesta and Klonopin or Ativan. I sleep but it’s never refreshing which makes me think I could possibly have CFS. Thank you for your suggestions...

I posted last fall when I was diagnosed with depression by my functional medicine doctor. She wanted me to do the genetic testing before prescribing anything since I am extremely sensitive to medications and have tried some anti depressants in the past which I had terrible problems with. Anyway the test came back with negatives to Lexapro...Celexa..( which I had bad results with).Also Zoloft the sleep med Belsomra (which didn’t work at all) and a bunch of pain meds were on the list. Then she decided she didn’t want to treat me and told me to see a psychiatrist that also specializes in medications. I can’t get in until late June. I called my PCP and she also had me fill out the questions about depression and I scored a 16 (5 or less means not depressed) I asked if I could try something while waiting for my appointment and she gave me Prozac since it was one of the “good” ones on my test. After five days I hadn’t horrible GI problems so I quit. Now a few weeks have passed and I am going to give it another try and hopefully tolerate the side effects since I really need to do something now ...I just wanted to say that the genetic test was pretty accurate because the meds that were negative I had tried some and they were really bad for me. It still is trial and error with the ones that are supposed to be okay so I am going to give it another go. If anyone has had bad experiences with medications and your insurance will cover the test it’s worth getting. I think we ended up paying 300.00 total and insurance covered the rest.

Hi ktp812,I am glad you were able to do the genetic testing and that it was accurate for you.  I hope you are getting relief from the depression now.  It is so hard when it is trial and error.  I was on five or six different medications before I found what was right for me.  Luckily now I have been on good antidepressants for about 19 or 20 years.  Keep posting and let us know how you are doing.  Thanks for the advice.Hugs, Karen...

@Karen- I am only on day four of restarting Prozac so I am in the very beginning. I so hope I get some relief within a few weeks. I am going to do my best to stick through any bad side effects. I definitely need therapy too but will have to wait until June. I am also taking  150 mg Wellbutrin in the morning because my PCP thought it would help with the chronic fatigue but it’s been 5 weeks and nothing yet. Although if I could get a good quality sleep would help immensely...

I wonder if you need more Wellbutrin?  But it can take six to eight weeks to notice a difference.  I took Wellbutrin years ago.  I needed a high dose at that time, but, the high dose gave me insomnia.  So I went on Effexor.  I did good on it for years  but when it went generic I couldn't get brand name so I switched to Pristiq.  I have been on that since 2010, and am doing well on it.  I take the highest dose.  I also take abilify (generic) and Xanax when needed.  It is hard to find what works.  I hope that the genetic testing becomes affordable to people who need it.  It would be worth it.  I hope that the Wellbutrin helps you.  If not, maybe Effexor or Pristiq would help.  They are close cousins I guess to each other.  I never did good on SSRI's (Prozac, Zoloft etc...), but when I switched to SNRI's I didn't get all the side effects that I got with the others.  Thanks for sharing.  I hope you have a good day...  And I hope that the therapy helps when you start...Hugs, Karen...

@Karen- I just looked over the genetic test and Effexor was also on the NO list so that won’t be an option. I was taking 150mg Wellbutrin twice a day but had bad side effects of metallic taste in my mouth..felt like it was burning...severe constipation...worse insomnia ..etc. The doctor had me cut back to once daily along with Prozac. I honestly don’t have much luck with anything...I don’t get alone well with medications but feel I have no choice if I want a life again. If this one doesn’t help there are others I can try and I will wait until I see the psychiatrist on June 18 to make any decisions. Yes I agree the genetic testing in the long run would save money and help people feel relief quicker because the doctors would have a head start on what to try...In fact the functional medicine doctor was going to try me on Effexor but decided to wait till the test results...good thing.Take care...Kim

Hi Kim,I am glad that the doctor waited and that you were able to have the testing.  It should be free for everybody I think but that is not likely to happen.  But it would make things so much easier for everybody concerned.  The Wellbutrin gave me a weird taste too once when I took it.  I tried it more than one time.  I guess that it is the same thing as zyban and that it is to help you stop smoking.  Zyban is suppose to make cigarettes taste bad.  Well the Wellbutrin made everything taste bad that time.  Probably because of taking a high dose.  I do have an option to try it again with the Pristiq, but at this point I don't think I need it.  I have chronic fatigue from fibromyalgia and I take Adderall for energy.  So I don't need the stimulant effect from the Wellbutrin.  I know how you feel about not having luck with medications and being sensitive to them.  It took me years to find something that worked.  Everything I would try would give me some type of side effect, even though it helped with depression, the side effects depressed me more.  Lately it has been the weather.  Here it is May tenth and it is snowing.  The sun tries tp peek out but it doesn't last long.  And it rains all the time.  I just pray for a day of sunshine so I can get out.  Wha…I hope you have a good day.  Hugs, Karen...

Hi Everyone,I've been very down this week , sad, depressed anxious. I havent had a pet in over 2 years from when my cat passed and we moved. I can't have pets where i am at the moment but when we buy a home in the next year i will be ableto get one again. Not having a pet has really changed me. I'm not ME. I'm used to caring for an animal. I don't quality for a therapy animal per my therapist. I have  a  hamster but its not the same. I'm just very depressed and its getting to me not having a cuddle buddy. Has/ or is anyone Having this issue right now or in the past? Thank you for listening. ~~~ Donna

Hi Donna,Welcome to the depression forum!  I know how you feel.  I Lost my beloved dog last May 15th.  I went without a pet until November 21st.  It was so empty.  But I did have a new found freedom of being able to come and go as I pleased without worrying about my pet.  So that was kind of nice.  My dog had separation anxiety..  Which in turn made me anxious to leave.I was surprised with a puppy on November 21, the day before Thanksgiving and my birthday.  I can tell you one thing, I wont be getting a pet in the winter again.  It has been very trying.  She goes potty on pads and I can't get her to go outside yet.  I been trying.  But I love her.  She is German Shepherd and all black except for two white toes on a back foot.  I named her Luna.Which would you like for a pet?  A cat or a dog?  I love dogs but a lot of people love cats.  One thing you do need to do is find you with or without a pet.  Learn to love the solitude of being alone.  You don't want to depend on anything else for fulfillment.  But I do understand how it is to be without a pet when you are use to having one.  Or more...  I hope you are able to buy a home next year and get a pet.  Maybe in the meantime go to the shelter and volunteer to help some pets there.  That may make you feel better.Have a good day and keep posting.Hugs, Karen...

We have had big dogs and dachshunds. When our last dachshund passed away last October, I only waited about 3 weeks before getting another small dog at the shelter because I felt I needed a lap dog to help with my depression also. (Our cat is not very snuggly) So I know how you feel. Karen has a good idea about going to a shelter. Ours has a cat room you can visit anytime without being a volunteer.

Welcome to the forum.I had an issue about 18yrs ago and did have a dog for while.I always had a dog, can't remember ever living without a dog except in my 20's when my parents refuse to let me take my dog with me.  Better security for them anyway. But I use to sleep with a cuddly pillow. Square and small.  The my husband bought me a teddy bear.  He's a chef and rarely home in the evenings.  The bear worked!  I still use it when I start panic attacks which is rare.  Between the bear and self-compassion practice I fared well with a pet for about 1.5years.PeaceTrina
Sending healing thoughts. HT.
JOVIHow are you feeling now?PeaceTrina

So I have felt myself sinking for a very long time within my emotions. Every year just seems to get worse, especially when I started at a university last year. I am a psychology student so I find myself relating a lot when the classes discuss depression and some hints of anxiety. The more I ponder, the more I feel like it relates to how I feel. I used to be a straight A’s and B’s student until around junior year of highschool. I slowly become more lazy and cared less and less about my grades. I had become content with just getting by. Since graduating highschool, that trend has continued and now I am to the point of failing college. As much as that hurts to admit, I find myself not really caring either. It isn’t that I’m not interested in the material. I love what I study but I have no motivation to do anything with my life. I am a very avid Gamer but even that has become biring and I find myself not enjoying that like I used to. I just lay around, and don’t want to move. I’ve always been a lazy individual but not to this extent. I used to go to work all through highschool, always on time, enjoyed going most days and making money. I cared about my grades for the most part I suppose. Now I just want to sleep and do nothing. Im sitting here and watching as my lack of motivation is causing everything to crumble around me. This bothers me and it causes me sadness but I just can’t find the motivation to act on it. I need to help myself but I can’t make myself. The worst part is seeing the disappointment in my parents. I despise letting them down and I can read it in their eyes every time they have to hear about my grades sucking or how I’m failing to do basic things like going to class or going to work on time. I feel needlessly tired all the time. I can sleep for almost 8-10 hours and still want to continue. I no longer hang out with any friends, not that I really ever did that much anyway, always been a real home body but I find myself watching my friends go out and do things that I would like to do but I always find myself refusing and deciding to just stay in my room. I always think to myself “what’s the point, they don’t think the way I do and I doubt I’ll meet anyone else that understands or accepts my views on stuff. I feel incredibly lonely I guess. At this point, I feel like I’m just rambling and I doubt anyone reads this far. It does feel nice to write out my thoughts though so I guess this is serving some slight purpose. I don’t really feel like I have anyone to talk to. I feel like therapy is the way to go and being a psychology student, instructors drill it in our mind that it’s fine to go but the though scares me. Sounds dumb since I plan to possibly being a counselor or therapist myself. I love the thought of helping others, but I don’t think I’ll get the chance if I don’t take the initiative to help myself. But even with that in mind. The financial issues, failing of classes, lack of wanting to do ANYTHING and overwhelming feeling of being alone is just too overpowering to pick myself up under. I don’t know what I’m seeking by spouting my thoughts here, I feel like I know what I need to do, I just can’t mind the willpower to act. Maybe someone can read and relate to how I’m feeling, at least they can feel like they aren’t the only ones. Am I the only one in this endless cycle of disappointment and failure, only to make myself feel worse as it continues to get bleaker.Post Edited By Moderator (getting by) : 4/30/2019 4:38:42 AM (GMT-6)

Hi Jukebox,I gave your post paragraphs to make for easier reading.  Please use paragraphs with long posts.  You know what you need to do.  Counseling.  Many therapists go to therapy themselves.  If you truly are a believer in what you want to do, I think you will go.  It would make life much easier right now.It is all up to you.  You make the final decision.  But as a person that has been going to therapy most of my life, I highly recommend it.I hope you go and that you feel better soon.  Only you can help yourself.Hugs, Karen...

If you are scared to go to therapy, tell yourself you'll just go once and see what it's like.  If I could give advice to my college self it would be to get therapy.  It would have saved me so much heartache and sadness.  Depression is hard to fix by yourself.  And, weirdly enough, the more you try to fix it yourself, the worse it gets.  So my advice is to get the phone number of the therapist, pick up the phone, take a deep breath and dial.  One visit is all you need to commit to to begin with and after that it will get easier.  You can do this, you are stronger than you think.

Jukebox,welcomethere is a resource thread at the top of the forum with 6 pages of valuable information.  I urge you to take a look.You say you are disappointing your parents.   I challenge that!  They may be worried, seeing the change in you running scenarios through their minds.  Perhaps the truth would be kinder.  Talking to them might help everyone.Why are you taking Psych courses?  Do you want to fight the Stigma in society?  The way you are feeling now, the struggles you are going through will make you a more compassion clinician.   Getting help is the first step to the journey you will be able to share in various ways with clients.Depression is a disease like another!  Honest.  You could simply have a chemical imbalance in your brain.  Easily controlled by medication.  What ever it is, It is not you fault!I strongly suggest, at the very least you reach out to the Wellness center at your college,  the nurse, whoever is there to help students.  You posted here,  you are a brave warrior looking for help!  You are not alone!  More people care than you know.Speaking out, seeking help is not showing weakness,  it is glowing with strength.     There are so many things in todays society that can cause depression.  The constant data input 24/7 is one. Please talk to some that will help you.  You deserve it.  Keep posting, let us know how things are goingPeace and strengthTrina
Jukeboxhow are you?

author: therearemiracles
title: Bupropion 75mg IR, clenching teeth and not sleeping well, flushing

postContent.comment: Hi!I have been on this for over a month and notice I’m tense in my jaw, flushing all day, don’t sleep well. It gives me energy and helps with my Crohn’s pain though. I read you can score and cut in half IR (instant release)pills.Maybe I will try that? Has anyone cut IR in half?Thanks, Linda

Have you discussed with your doctor?  It sounds like it is too stimulating for you.  Though you could get use to it in time.  I would talk to the doc before cutting the dose.I hope you feel better soon.  Bupropion is a good medication but was too stimulating for me.  It gave me insomnia.  I can take it in small doses but not high doses.Hugs, Karen...
definitely discuss his with doc or pharmacistpeaceTrina

I'm having a depression today so I might as well share.  After I type this I am going to look at the depression resources.  I just don't want to do anything today.  Trying to make that all right.  I don't have a lot going on in my life except helping my sister get ready to move, a weekly trip to the acunpuncturist.  I have two support groups that i usually attend, I am skipping one today.I did take a shower and shave and that always make me feel better.  Fighting the good fight with quitting smoking.  I decided to just ignore the "advice" some people give that it is extra hard to quit if you have mental health issues.I have some shopping I need to do.  I used to (several years ago) accomplish that without too much trouble.  Don't know why it's such a big deal, but I do get worried about not buying the right size in clothes.My parents always called us lazy if we didn't have something to do.  Even though that was a long time ago, i think it still affects my feelings.Thanks for listening.  Feedback encouraged.

Yeah, I get the "lazy if you aren't doing something" feeling.  My Dad was constantly saying, "Do something, even if it's wrong!"  I've had to let it "be okay" to just nap or daydream if that's all I'm able to do. It takes work to reprogram those childhood messages - but now we are adults, and we get to choose whether we still believe them or not! Good luck.

Hi Rich,I totally know how you feel when you say you use to do things and it wasn't a big deal, but now it is.  I been procrastinating going out myself.  There is so much I need to do and I don't want to do anything.  And to go somewhere is so difficult anymore.  All I know is to try to do things.  They often become easier once we get started.  But I think for me, the thought of doing them causes some anxiety.  I take a Xanax before I go anywhere.  It makes it a little easier to leave.  I feel it is okay to give ourselves a break once in awhile and just do nothing.  Maybe watch a movie, or cook something you like and just enjoy the day.The weather has been crappy here lately.  Tomorrow is May and it is still cold and gloomy.  Damp...  We are having nice weather (supposedly) Saturday and Sunday.  I look forward to that.  I usually walk my dog but yesterday it snowed and rained and today it is only 30 degrees.  Wha….  excuses I have....When our parents call us lazy I think it makes us feel guilty if we aren't constantly doing something.  Try not to let it effect you and how you feel.  They weren't always right.I hope your day gets better Rich.  Take the day and relax, I think I am going to.Hugs, Karen...

I absolutely know what you what mean RichI am 58,  our generation always had to be busy.was not allowed to just sit and watch TV.  Fold clothes,  mend clothes, etc.  always productive.Still to this day,  crocheting or embroidery while watching TV. Rare I can sit still and watchShopping gets harder for me each year.  Clothes!?   I avoid it at all costs!   Food shopping, temped to have it delivered now,  but need to go.  Once out it does feel go,  getting myself past the door most days it the issue.Pain is my nemesis.   I control with weed and Tylenol 4 when severe.   I need to go out in am when pain is low.I want to go to a meditation prayer group Tuesday nights, but by 6pm I am down for the night.  Sigh.Accepting limitations is hard to deal with.   We need to work around them.  Push ourselves at times. Find a good balance. Hope you are feeling better soon.PeaceTrina

Dear Trina, Karen and Lynnwood,Thanks for your replies.  All of them helped me.  Today I just made up my mind I was going out to buy some t-shirts.  Due to increased weight, some of mine don't fit anymore, and then when I lean over you can see too much.  Anyway, I prayed for help.  Now I have gone and am back.  It wasn't really that hard.  I did have the memory of when I was a teenager I LOVED to shop for clothes.  But that was a long time ago.  Maybe I can resuscitate those feelings.Have a great day!

That's awesome Rich!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!I, myself, am using the weather as an excuse right now.  It is damp, rainy and cold.  But this weekend is suppose to be nice, sunny and warm.  So I plan to go out then.  Tomorrow is suppose to be warmer than today so maybe even tomorrow.  I ache when it is cold due to fibromyalgia.  That is why I don't like going out when it is cold, especially damp.  See I have a lot of excuses to not go out.  But when the weekend comes I will have to go, so this is only temporary for me.  I am glad you got out and got t-shirts.  I am glad you had a good memory too.  I think you can regain the feelings, though they will probably be a temporary type thing, but still there.I hope you have another and another good day.  Many...  Keep up the great work!!!Hugs, Karen...

Little background....My 14 year old was diagnosed a little over a year ago with depression, anxiety and suicidal ideology.  We've had a few ER visits and 1 inpatient recommendation that was for about a week stay.  He's been seeing a therapist, which has been going very well and taking medication to help with the depression.  about a month and a half ago, my husband found an ice tea can that was actually something to hide things in.  My husband texted me and said he found weed in it.  When I spoke with my son about it, he said there was no weed, but there was a pipe and a lighter.  I had a talk with my son about the possibility of him smoking and that I knew I couldn't stop him from doing so.  He admitted to me that he had before and that he feels that it helps him with his symptoms of depression and anxiety.          My husband, who is his step-father, was obviously furious when he found that can.  He was upset that he brought it into the house.  When I had the talk with my son before this incident, I specifically told him that under no circumstances is he allowed to bring anything like that into the house.  During the talks my husband and I have had, he's more upset about the fact that he brought something into the house and he believes can risk his 2 sons from being allowed to come to our house if his ex were to find out.  I briefly spoke to my son about the situation because I thought we were going to sit down as a family to discuss the matter so I didn't go into much detail about anything.       Fast forward, it has been about a month and a half and my husband has not said 1 word to my son about anything.  And when I say anything, I mean anything.  He has not spoken to him AT ALL.  For about the first 3 weeks my son didn't want to come out of his room.  He didn't eat dinner until we went to bed because he was afraid of what my husband might say.  My husband noticed he wasn't coming out of his room and he said it was probably a good idea because he would blow up at him.  My son finally made the decision that he wasn't going to hide in his room anymore and he now comes out to eat when dinner is actually ready.  He pretty much went back to acting like things were normal, save the fact my husband refuses to talk to him.      Now it seems that it's at the point to where if my son does anything wrong, my husbands mind goes back to finding the can and gets frustrated all over again.  My sons likes incense.  He has for quite some time.  The other day he was burning one and my husband automatically jumped to the conclusion that he is only burning them because he wants to hide the smell of weed.  I went into his room and didn't smell anything that smelt like weed.  It's a pretty distinctive smell.  My son and I went to the store and my husband text me saying "House smells like weed.  I need to know if he had it in the house again."  I showed my son the text and he told me no, that he hasn't brought anything into the house.  He even admitted to me there was no weed in can, just the pipe and lighter.  My husband even admitted that he didn't even look in the can, he just opened it and smelt it.       I'm sorry for the long post, I just feel that I'm caught in the middle because my husband won't even talk to my son about anything.  They've had a pretty good relationship up until this point and I don't want this to ruin it.  I'm trying to being understanding on both sides of this, but I do feel like if it were his 14 year old that did the same thing, he wouldn't give him the silent treatment for over a month.  Yes, he would be upset with him, but he wouldn't be giving him the same treatment he's giving my son.  I want to bring it up to him, but part of me is afraid of what his reaction will be like.  He's a pretty stubborn person and almost has the mentality that it's his way and his time or nothing at all and gets pretty frustrated when it's not.  Any help would be so appreciated.Thank you for taking the time to read.

Is marijuana legal or illegal where you are?  It is legal here in Michigan.  But I think the legal age is either 18 or 21, I am not sure.  I have a medical marijuana card myself.  I think with your husband and your son's relationship, you may just have to let it take it's course.  You can't make them get along.  I think your son is willing but your husband is not.  I would just go with the flow of it for now.  You could try to get them to go to counseling maybe???  Again, I think your son would be more willing than your husband would.  Your son is 14?  I do admit that marijuana helps with depression.  Some people it helps with anxiety and some it makes worse.  Though your son says it helps his anxiety.  But I do agree on the depression.  Though I think counseling will help your son a lot.  I take medications for depression and anxiety too.No, you cannot force your husband to go easier on your son, but I think in time he will.  How old are his sons?  I am sure that they aren't perfect.  But I can also understand how he feels about being able to see his kids too.Your son isn't going to bring it in the house anymore.  That is what he said, and it sounds like he is honest.  I would just reinforce it with him from time to time and kind of relax and just see how things go.  Like I said, you can't change your husband or your son for that matter.  But it sounds like your son wants to get along and that is half the battle.I wish you the best.  Welcome to the depression forum.  I hope that things work out for all of you.  May I ask where your husband found the can?  Was it in your son's room?  If so, what was your husband doing in his room?  Just wondering.  Again, I really hope that things work out.  You sound like a cool person.  How does your son do in school?  Does he smoke it a lot?  The reason I ask is that he is young.  And he is learning.  Though I did it at the same age.  I am not proud of it, but it is fact.  Just make sure he continues counseling.  I think that will help him the most.Hugs, Karen...

Thank you for your response Karen.  I'm really hopeful that things just run it's course with this situation.  I feel uncomfortable in my own home.  Which I'm sure my son and husband probably feel the same.  I totally get what you mean about how sometimes it doesn't help with the anxiety and could actually make it worse because my son has told me that there have been times it's made it worse.  He and I have a really close relationship and he's pretty open with me about things.  Where my husband found the can was in my son's room, however, my son leaves his door open when he leaves for school and the can was laying on the floor right next to his bed.  We have a no drink and food in rooms rule for the boys so my son made the "mistake" of just leaving it out in the open and my husband saw it.  He actually recognized it right away as a "stash can" because he said that he had one when he was younger.  I think the legal age in Washington is either 18 or 21, I'm not quite sure, so he's obviously not of legal age.  My son is having his struggles in school, but I don't think it has anything to do with smoking.  He's had issues years before this situation happened.  He doesn't smoke a lot from what I know.  I can't say how many times he has, but I know it's not like every day.  My guess it possibly, before this issue, around once to twice a week.  I smoked as well around his age and I didn't feel that going into full parent mode and just forget everything that I was feeling and going though myself when I was his age was going to help.  So having that conversation with him was easier since he knew I wasn't going to explode on him.I just don't know how long I should let this go on for before I say something.  I just want my house back to 'normal'.

That probably all depends on when your husband lets go.  I hope he isn't picking on your son with this.  Especially if he did it himself.  But I think in time he will let it go.  And I too hope that things get back to normal soon.  It is no fun not feeling comfortable in your own home.  I have had that feeling before and I truly didn't like it.  I think it makes me paranoid or not feel safe.  Emotionally I think.I don't blame you for not wanting to say anything, but if he keeps pushing and punishing your son verbally I guess, I think I would say something.  I don't like confrontations so I don't say things and then situations get out of hand.  Then everybody blows up.  Or sometimes I don't know the proper way to approach things.  It is hard.I hope that everything works out okay.  Feel free to keep posting if you want to.  I hope I am of some help.  Sometimes it is hard to be objective of situations.  Take care...Hugs, Karen...

Hi. This is weird for me as I don’t share my feelings ever with anyone. This is my first post. I just don’t see the point. I regret getting married and I regret having kids. I have bought kids into this awful world . I’m a misery guts my hubby has to put up with. I feel like he’s wasting his time with me and so  I have told him to look for someone else but he won’t. I feel so ashamed and useless to all of them and I’m trapped here. I’m so darn ugly I have refused to have my photo taken for the last 5 years. I feel pathetic just writing this stuff. I saw a dr last year about depression but he didn’t take me seriously. I just look forward to sleeping. But hey I’m excellent at faking happiness!! I’ve got that going for me! Good night for now. Xx

Hi Tanem,Welcome to the depression forum.  I am good at faking happiness too.  But it works for me.  When I do, I don't dwell on things that make me unhappy.  So that is truly a talent.Try seeing a psychiatrist or a therapist.  Or tell your doctor you seriously think you need some help.  I am sure that they will take you seriously this time.  You are not ugly.  You may be to yourself but not others.  Beauty is in the EYE of the BEHOLDER.  People see others differently.   Different than we see ourselves...I am sorry you have regrets of having a family.  Who knows your child may change the world.  We can't change what we have done with our lives.  So the best thing is to make the most of what we have.  Love your family.  Love your husband..  It sounds like he really loves you a lot.Hang in there Tanem.  Keep posting as it helps.Hugs, Karen...

Sometimes writing things down brings a certain clarity.  I've never been 'attractive' and the older I get the less likely it is that I would be asked to be a cover on a magazine!  What attracted my partner to me was NOT my looks.  She tells me it is my confidence.  The world is a mess, that's for sure...but it IS our children and grandchildren that will be the ones to change it from it's present trajectory after all. Do not regret them...they may hold the cure for cancer in their minds...yet to be discovered.  I, too, feel useless to others much of the time, but that is only depression talking.  Without me, my daughter and grandson would be homeless.  My pets would probably languish in a shelter.  I hope you will try to see things from a different perspective.

Welcome T to the forumWe all have felt the way you do at one time or another.   I urge you to seek out another doctor.  Not taking you seriously is not right.  You have an illness that needs treatment.In the meantime journaling is a good idea.  I write every day.  Is is great that you can pour out your feelings, true feelings and a lot of the rumination goes away because you can rationalize things. Self compassion is a good start in challenging the thoughts and feelings you have.   Here is a link that has many articles that may help you.  [url]http://psychology.com[/ur]I definitely think therapy and a psychiatrist would be very helpful. I wish you peace and strengthTrina

Thanks for all your kind words. Please know I adore my kids and my hubby. I just feel they deserve better. I guess I more regret not being the best for them ( and that this world is mean and scary).Despite me, the kids are great people.But they will grow into adults one day and see the real me. I hope they spread their wings and don’t look back. As for my hubby, sometimes I frown upon him because I can’t believe he wants me. What’s wrong with him ?? He’s never been with another woman... there are thousands out there better than me. I feel like I’m depriving him from knowing other things because he stays true to his vows. I don’t want him to have regrets. He is still young enough to experience others. I can barely look him in the eyes for the guilt I feel at holding him back. No we don’t talk about feelings. He prefers to keep things superficial. I’m sorry for rambling. I’ll go now. T

Hi Tanem,Your husband loves you for you.  Beauty is only skin deep.  And as I said before, it is in the eyes of the beholder.  Try not to think about looks.  Look at what is inside the person, you.  You are a beautiful person.  Remember that.Hugs, Karen...

My kids are now 25 and 23 years old.  I still worry about being a depressed mom when they were growing up - part of my depression narrative.  But when I look at it rationally, they have grown up to be great adults.  They now know all about my depression and it is OK.  They don't love me any less.  My younger son has inherited my  dysthymia and it actually makes it easier for us to talk about it because he knows I've been there.

I go to a sliding scale clinic for therapy as I have no insurance. At the clinic they also offer psychiatric services. I've always been ambivalent about taking medication although I've taken it in the past.  However, I'm more open to it now as my mood and anxiety seem to swing-one minute I'm down, the next I feel normal. My issue is with the clinic. It took quite a while just to get an appointment with a psychiatrist. My appointment is this Saturday. Problem is I have something really important to do this Saturday and the next available appointment is in June! I also am not comfortable with the fact that you have to wait a long time to see the psychiatrist. What if I have an issue with my meds and need to see someone right away.  I don't know what to do.Post Edited (ForeverPositive) : 4/22/2019 10:36:25 AM (GMT-6)

I would try to make the appointment.  Once you are into the system, things should go faster for you.  And you can talk to somebody over the phone about medication problems.  My psychiatrist is retiring, but I see his nurse for medications and therapy.  She is also a psychologist.  But whenever I have a problem with anything, I call her.  Luckily she will be able to continue to write my prescriptions that he usually writes.  I know it isn't always convenient for you but unless you have other options, you will have to go with what they offer.  I don't think anywhere gets you in real quick with your first visit to a psychiatrist.  You have to kind of find a spot and go from there.  I would really try to make that appointment especially since you will have to wait a month to get another one.  Your mental health is important.I hope you feel better soon.Hugs, Karen...
Make the appointment but also ask to be called if someone cancels for an earlier appointment.
Excellant suggestion pitmom..However if they don't do that..  How about putting a few reminders in your phone to call back and check to see if any times have opened up. Peace and strength Trina

Congratulations on taking that step to see a psychiatrist  - that can be tough to do!  Now that you have made that decision, I think it is important that you follow through so that you don't have second thoughts about it.  Hang in there, and sorry if I sound like a mom (cuz that's what I am)

Hello, I just joined Healing Well.  I have been reading your posts for about a month and feel like you are a great group of people.I don't have an exciting life story but I will tell you a little about myself.  I have had chronic depression since childhood.  Fortunately, I had a great childhood and a good life so far.  The depression runs in my family.  For me, the bad depression is triggered by stressful events.  For example, when I was diagnosed with pre-diabetes out of the blue without any risk factors, I went into a tailspin for several months. But I have always managed to function.  I got through school, raised a couple of kids and continue to work.  I have tried many different antidepressants and am currently on duloxetine, which is semi helpful.  Combined with therapy, I seem to do OK.  I also get a lot of help from exercise, which I am hoping to get back to in 1-2 months since I just had a hip replacement.I live in a little town in the mountains. I am married and have 2 sons, 22 and 25.  My 25 year old is living with us temporarily since finishing graduate school.  My mother in law also lives with us, along with a boatload of various pets, so we are quite a full household.  My favorite thing to do is hike. Summer is coming!I am hoping to make some friends here and talk to other people who have similar issues.  I hide my depression from everyone else.Cheers!

for the past few weeks I've been slowly spiraling out of control. I just feel like a failure and a reject, all the bad feelings are coming rushing back. I just feel hollow and lonely. I've always felt this way, but its been a while since a depressive episode has brought all of it back. When I was younger I used to be talkative and outgoing, but after I had finished junior high I was a depressive, anti-social outcast. If I had to guess I would say this was mostly due to me being bullied for most of my school years before high school. I never really had many close friends, and it seems the few that I do have rarely stick around for long. I've never been in a relationship, I wouldn't even know where to begin one. So I've always felt lonely, like there is a piece of me missing. I've tried to fill this emptiness with different hobbies and interests but it's never more than a band-aid. Right now I feel like nobody outside my family notices me, I put on a plastic smile, gel up my hair, and dress nicely in the morning only to be invisible. I feel like I'm putting up this elaborate facade for no one, like everything I do is futile. All I want is someone to care about me, and someone I can care about. No matter how hard I try I worry I will always be alone. I don't want to wind up like my dad, who never found love until he was almost in his forties. I don't know how much longer I can put up with feeling like this.

Hi Constant...First of all I guess I wouldn't care about what others think of me.  But that is me.  I am older and I don't try to impress anybody.  They can take me the way I am or not.Do you go to any therapy?  It really helps.  Are you on any medication for depression?  You may want to talk to your doc about it.You are trying and that is what is important.  Talk to your doc about medication and therapy.  See if it helps.  A lot of us go through this.  Self help tools help a lot too.  Check out our depression resources at the top of the page.  You may find some helpful information.Keep posting as it helps.  We are here for you.Hugs, Karen...

thanks KarenI've been through therapy before, and I've been in and out of the system for nearly half of my life. I'm not currently in therapy right now, and I don't want to go back unless I have to. I do realize though that it may become necessary soon. I've never really looked into trying anti-depressants and it may be worth trying. It just feels like therapy has been little more than a band-aid, usually I'm out of therapy for less than a year before I need to go back again.

Maybe you just haven't gotten to the bottom of things.  I don't think I have.  But I think those things come more when we are ready to deal with them.  Kind of like repressed memories or something.  They surface when you are mentally able to deal with them.  I take medications for depression.  They help, but it took me a long time to find what was right for me.  There are so many of them.  But I have to admit they do help.  It takes awhile though for them to work good.  So it is a longer process than we would like.  I am glad you are open to therapy if you need it.  I have a tendency to not talk about things that bother me.  I don't know why I do that.  I guess because I have been going for so long.  But it is like when I get there I forget what is bothering me.  Strange.  I do that with the doctor too.  I usually write things down.  That helps.I hope you feel better soon Constant...Hugs, Karen...

Welcome to the forum constantyou are so NOT alone in this world.  So many people go through life like this.  People you think that have it all go home to empty apts. and houses. I myself ended up marrying a Chef I. met at work.  We were friends first.  Long story short.  I was abused, surpassed it all.  Now I realized I married him be it comfortable.  He would never be home and I would not have to work on a relationship.  an like most Chefs,  [I am sure there are exceptions]. he cheated, a lot]After 30yrs of married are separated,  working back towards friends.  Who needs more enemies right?I have only started to make from friends from a support group I have been going to for 5years.  They start slow and developed over coffee,  a lunch here and there.  Some wrecked, some I shut down.  But I learned to see and feel if a person was using me for a cab service or whatever, or if we really genuinely liked each other.And I also found out that friends do not have to daily, in your face talking.  Adults and spend weeks with out seeing a person and still have a warm friendship.  Heck you can build a friendship around the world today and never meet the person, but love them all the same.   May I suggest Self compassion.  It helped me so much to challenge the negative  thoughts about myself and when that happened I realized the things bullies and others said about me were not true.  I am a beautiful and good person.  And so are you!!!At the top of this forum is a thread,  Resources.  about 5 pages of helpful information,.  on the last pages is a list of books.  Take and look and try to start loving yourself.Peace strength and hugsTrina
